From dawn to dusk, he might utter not a single word. His disciples approached and said: “Master, you remain silent—how can your disciples expound? You differ not from the common man.”

I privately thought: If the great bell does not sound, it is no different from a heap of bronze; if the floating chime ceases its tone, it is indistinguishable from a pile of stones.

Master Tranquil and Profound replied: “I seek only to gather a distant name across ten thousand generations and find a true friend in the ages to come. How could I vie for recognition in this day or set my standard in this moment? A vessel for brewing fine wine, though excellent, does not itself become drunk. One who speaks humbly yet loftily, though correct, is not believed. To curl the tongue and exhaust the voice—what remedy is there for fleeing and evasion? The ancients laughed at fifty-nine when they reached sixty; only then did they realize the depth of their past delusion.

For jade is hard, and gold is strong.”

The cold of ice and the heat of fire—do they require self-proclamation to be known? Moreover, the eight tones and nine suites cannot avoid flaws of length or brevity; even Yang You’s hundred shots cannot prevent an occasional miss. Those who cross rivers without boats often drown in water; those fond of heated debate frequently slip in speech. Bo Ya was cautious with his strings, thus avoiding the burden of tangled fingers; the scholar guards his words, thus escaping the shame of careless slips. The shallow and vulgar act otherwise: they dispute the urgency of emptiness and nothingness, squander words on trivial matters, and expound at length on the useless doctrines of "hard and white." They litigate against the masters, condemn the sages, and fault the upright, calling such misguidance "profound." They cast aside the true classics to vie in heterodox studies, or match wits with the ignorant in contests of lip and tongue, spouting lofty discourse to those who cannot comprehend. Before those who cannot contend, with no discerning audience at hand, how is this different from playing refined music beside wooden effigies or displaying alchemical elixirs before clay idols?

In vain their mouths grow parched, their qi exhausted, their bold gestures like axes dulled and splintered—yet the knot remains unbroken. Their faces flush with agitation, their discord grows ever more distant, until anger distorts their countenance, shameful words escape their lips, and the shift toward pettiness arises. Once such flaws are stained, they cannot be mended. Far better to embrace silence to preserve the great tone, to restrain speech and await those who truly understand.

*Self-Narration, Fifty-First*

The Master of Embracing Simplicity, surnamed Ge, named Hong, styled Zhichuan, was a native of Jurong in Danyang. His ancestors descended from the Ge Tian clan, who once ruled all under heaven in ancient times. Later, they were demoted to the ranks of feudal lords and took Ge as their surname. Hong’s great-grandfather served as Inspector of Jingzhou. When Wang Mang usurped the throne, he scorned to serve a traitorous regime, resigned his post, and returned home. Together with Zhai Yi, Governor of Dongjun, he raised troops to punish Wang Mang but was defeated. Pardoned and spared from disaster, he feigned illness and withdrew from the world. Fearing that the Ge clan’s strength might eventually provoke unrest, Wang Mang relocated them to Langye. Hong’s grandfather, Pu, raised an army to aid Emperor Guangwu, rendering great service. After Guangwu ascended the throne, Pu was appointed General of Chariots and Cavalry, later promoted to General of Agile Cavalry, and enfeoffed as Marquis of Xiapei and Tongxian, with a fief of five thousand households. At the founding of the dynasty, Pu’s younger brother, Wen, followed the marquis on campaigns and achieved repeated victories. The marquis repeatedly memorialized the throne to commend Wen’s merits, but the court, citing Wen’s private service under his elder cousin without official military rank, refused to acknowledge his contributions. The marquis declared, “My brother and I together faced arrows and stones, our bodies covered in wounds, my right eye lost—yet he has received no reward, while I am laden with gold and purple. How can my heart be at ease?” He then petitioned to transfer his own enfeoffment to his brother. The emperor, wishing to honor the marquis’s noble integrity, granted the request. Wen, though reluctant, accepted the title and immediately ceded his residence to become the encampment of the General of Agile Cavalry, establishing his estate in Bowang Ward. To this day, its foundations and stone pillars remain. He also divided his stipends to provide for his officers and soldiers, treating them as generously as the two former marquises. The General of Agile Cavalry repeatedly urged him to desist, but Wen refused, saying, “This only burdens the people further. How can I accept?” Feigning other business, he crossed the Yangtze southward and settled in Jurong, where his descendants tilled the land and found solace in books. Though Wen repeatedly sent envoys to welcome the General of Agile Cavalry, the latter never returned. Instead, he stationed guards to maintain the estate in Bowang, hoping for the general’s eventual return—yet for generations, no one resided there.

Hong’s grandfather was a scholar of unparalleled breadth, mastering all fields of learning with profound precision. His literary and artistic attainments stood peerless in his time, and he possessed the talent to govern a state. Serving the Kingdom of Wu, he held successive posts as Magistrate of Haiyan, Lin’an, and Shanyin, then entered the capital as Gentleman of the Ministry of Personnel, Palace Aide to the Censor-in-Chief, Governor of Luling, Minister of Personnel, Junior Preceptor to the Crown Prince, President of the Imperial Secretariat, Grand Master of Ceremonies, Palace Attendant, and Intendant of the Palace Guards. He was also appointed General of Assisting Wu and enfeoffed as Marquis of Wushou. Hong’s father was renowned for his filial piety and fraternal devotion, a model for scholars. His conduct and learning were exhaustively recorded in official histories. He served Wu as Gentleman of the Five Offices, Prefect of Jiancheng and Nanchang, Gentleman of the Imperial Secretariat, and Minister of Justice, then as General of the Guards. He was appointed Governor of Kuaiji but had not yet assumed office when the Jin army advanced downstream, and the western borders collapsed. Recognizing his literary and martial talents, the court and populace unanimously recommended him. He was thus transferred to serve as Commander-in-Chief of Five Commanderies, charged with defending the frontier, granted five thousand personal troops, and placed in command of all expeditionary forces. Yet when heaven decrees ruin, human effort cannot prevail. As the former lord submitted to the Nine Provinces’ shared fate, Hong’s father, retaining his former rank, was summoned to serve as Gentleman of the Palace, gradually rising to the position of Grand Master of Splendid Happiness. He later served as Magistrate of Feixiang, a county of twenty thousand households, where his governance was deemed the finest in the province. His moral transformation was exceptional, his benevolence pervasive, his punishments just, and his domain peaceful, earning him widespread praise. Roads were free of bandits, and no one tilled public fields or crossed boundaries to trade. Even the smallest gifts were refused at his gate, while paper and brushes were supplied from his private funds. Through punishments, order was maintained; without words, transformation was achieved. He resigned due to illness, but an imperial edict summoned him to serve as Prefect of Wu, where he upheld strict integrity, correcting errors, promoting the worthy, and exposing the corrupt. The state and military were governed with solemn harmony. Later, he was appointed Governor of Shaoling and died in office.

Hong was his father’s third son. Born late in his parents’ lives, he was doted upon and not strictly disciplined in books and history. At the age of thirteen, he lost his kind father, prematurely deprived of paternal instruction. Struggling with hunger and cold, he personally tilled the fields, laboring beneath the stars and treading upon frost, diligently following the plow. Repeatedly ravaged by war and fire, his family’s books were utterly destroyed. During rare moments of respite from farming, with nothing to read, he carried his satchel and walked to borrow books, only to find that few households possessed complete collections. Thus, he redoubled his efforts, cutting and selling firewood to purchase paper and brushes, writing books by the light of kindling in his thatched hut. For this reason, he could not early immerse himself in the arts and literature. Often lacking paper, he wrote on the same sheets repeatedly, rendering his texts barely legible. At sixteen, he began studying the *Classic of Filial Piety*, the *Analects*, the *Book of Songs*, and the *Book of Changes*. Yet poverty prevented him from seeking distant teachers and friends, leaving him isolated and poorly informed, his thoughts shallow and his understanding limited. Many great principles remained beyond his grasp. Eager to read widely, he devoured all manner of books, memorizing whatever he encountered. Yet his nature was dull and forgetful, his will not steadfast, and his retention weak. Though he sometimes drew upon his readings in his writings, he never achieved the depth of a true Confucian scholar and was unfit to serve as a teacher. The *River Chart* and *Luo Writing*, along with apocryphal texts, he merely glanced at without deep engagement. He disliked astrological manuals, calculations, the Nine Palaces, three-player chess, *Taiyi* divination, and flying talismans, finding no affinity for such arts. Later, he dabbled in wind angles, qi observation, the Three Origins, *Dunjia*, *Liuren*, and *Taiyi* methods, gaining only a rough understanding without deep study. He concluded that such practices were tools for others’ use, mere distractions from self-cultivation. Believing that reducing desires was more beneficial, he abandoned them. According to the *Separate Record of Arts and Letters*, there were 13,299 volumes of books, and since the Wei dynasty, the corpus had doubled. Thus, he realized how much he had yet to see. Books from the south of the Yangtze were incomplete, and he once journeyed to the capital in search of rare and extraordinary texts, only to be thwarted by great chaos, forcing him to turn back midway. Each time, he sighed with regret. Now nearing forty, his youthful aspirations have waned. He thinks only of diminishing desires further, practicing non-action, and perhaps retiring to the marshes to preserve his life. His pursuit of broad learning has thus daily declined.

Ge Hong was a man of simple and rustic bearing, dull by nature, slow of speech, and plain in appearance, yet he never sought to adorn or refine himself. His hats and shoes were filthy and worn, his robes often tattered, and he felt no shame in this. As worldly fashions swiftly changed—now broad collars and wide sashes, now tight sleeves and long hems, now trailing skirts, now garments too short to cover the feet—he remained steadfast in his ways, refusing to follow the shifts of the age. His words were always plain and truthful, free of jest or mockery. When no suitable companion was at hand, he would pass the entire day in silence. Thus, all who knew him called him a man who "embraced simplicity," and so he took this as the title for his writings.

By nature, Ge Hong was frail and sickly, and poverty left him without carriage or horse. He could not bear to walk, nor did he enjoy it, and he despised the degenerate customs of his time—how men abandoned fundamentals to chase trivialities, how they overindulged in socializing. Thus, he took up his brush in seclusion, dwelling in stillness behind a wattle gate, with no place to rush to or follow after. Even those in power, though near at hand, scarcely knew him. His clothes could not ward off the cold, his roof could not keep out the rain, and his food could not fill his stomach. Yet fame never crossed his threshold, and he could not bring himself to care. Poor, with no servants, his fences collapsed, brambles choked his courtyard, and weeds overran his steps. When he ventured out, he pushed through thickets; when he returned, he brushed past overgrowth. Observers thought him lofty of mind, neglectful of the mundane, and never resentful of his hardships.

Unskilled in formal visits, he never paid respects to officials. Yet when it came to mourning the dead or tending to the sick, he would force himself to go, sparing no effort. But his frailty and frequent illnesses often left him unable to fulfill these duties, and critics would reproach him. Ge Hong accepted the blame without concern. He thought: if his intentions were pure and illness alone prevented him, why should he feel shame? What reason had others not to understand? Only those of clear discernment would forgive him, recognizing that his embrace of simplicity was not a ploy to cultivate loftiness.

Most men cherished the warmth of close bonds and prized the intimacy of those who came to them in ignorance. Ge Hong, however, believed that truly knowing another was no easy task—even the sages found it difficult. Superficial friendships, where words aligned but minds clashed, brought no benefit, only harm. Though he could not sever ties as abruptly as Zhuangzi’s friend did, he insisted on clarity and thorough understanding before committing to a relationship. For this, he was deeply resented, yet he never changed.

Those who chased success and stood obsequiously at the gates of the powerful despised Ge Hong for his difference, slandering him as arrogant and dismissive of custom. But Ge Hong was a man of unwavering conviction; praise and blame alike fell on deaf ears. He loathed those who, relying on their own strengths, belittled the weaknesses of others. As one of the least among Confucians, when he spoke with others, he always gauged their understanding and discussed only what they could grasp, never forcing them toward what they could not comprehend.

When debating with scholars, he would lay out the essentials. If he encountered someone of limited ability, he would offer only a rough sketch of his ideas, just enough to spark insight, without pressing the finer points to the point of confusion. Those who listened with a calm mind and pondered deeply often found their own realizations. When he judged someone unfit for discussion, even if questioned, he would plead ignorance to avoid wasting words.

By nature, Ge Hong deeply disliked imposing on officials or superiors. From youth to old age, he had secretly aided several friends in distress, yet none knew it was he who had helped them. He could not bear to see others wronged and would quietly intervene on their behalf. But for all others—even close relatives—if they held power or influence and were strangers to him, he would not trouble them with so much as a word or half a character.

When his supplies ran low and he urgently needed medicine, he would ask friends for help, and if they provided, he accepted without refusal. Any assistance he received, he repaid gradually over time, ensuring the giver never noticed. If the aid did not come from a friend, he would not accept it. When his own provisions lasted ten days, he would share them to relieve others’ needs. But if his own stores were insufficient, he would not deprive himself.

He did not strive for petty displays of virtue or meticulous scruples. Among villagers, those deemed "good and kind" would sometimes bring wine and dishes to visit him. Though he did not consider them his equals, he did not refuse them. If he later repaid the gesture, he did not do so immediately.

Ge Hong once remarked on the historian’s account of a man who refused to eat with his brothers but kept his table spotless for guests: such was the false conduct of those seeking fame, not the magnanimity of a statesman. He particularly despised those without principle—men who neglected the fundamentals of farming and weaving to pursue illicit gains. Some sold official appointments for bribes; others exploited their influence to extort wealth. Some took bribes from criminals, others wronged the innocent. Some harbored fugitives and sheltered outlaws; others conscripted laborers to obstruct public works. Some hoarded goods to inflate prices; others monopolized markets to seize profits from the people. Some seized fields and robbed the weak of their livelihoods. They cowered before officials, seeking opportunities to exploit, then flaunted their gains before their wives and concubines or used them to buy fame and rank. With such men, Ge Hong refused all association.

Thus, the worldly despised him, and naturally, they kept their distance. No carriage tracks marred his lane, no guests of differing minds crossed his hall. His courtyard could have been set with bird nets, and his tables gathered dust. From the time he first gained understanding until his later years, his lips never uttered another’s faults, nor did he delight in others’ secrets—this came naturally to him. Even his servants, if they had shortcomings or shameful acts, he never mocked. He never judged or ranked people’s strengths and weaknesses, nor did he enjoy scolding others. If pressed by superiors to speak of someone’s likes or dislikes, he would only mention their finest qualities. When discussing writing, he would highlight its best aspects, never pointing out its flaws. Thus, he incurred no resentment for praise or blame.

When powerful men occasionally asked him about officials or commoners—who was pure, who was capable—he would extol the virtues of the upright and talented. For the greedy, violent, or ignorant, he would claim to know nothing of them. For this, he was often criticized, accused of being overly cautious, unable to clearly distinguish right from wrong. Yet Ge Hong never altered his ways.

He often saw how people, when discussing others, would compare and rank them, their praise and criticism often misplaced. Those who were praised would take it as their due, though their virtue might not be genuine. Those who were slighted would hate their detractors to the bone, as if they were blood enemies. Ge Hong took this as a warning and thereafter never spoke of others.

When engaging with scholars, he would grasp the main points. If he encountered someone of limited understanding, he would offer only a rough outline of his ideas, just enough to inspire insight, without pressing the finer points to the point of confusion. Those who listened with a calm mind and pondered deeply often found their own realizations. If he judged someone unfit for discussion, even if questioned, he would plead ignorance to avoid wasting words. His nature deeply disliked imposing on officials or superiors. From youth to old age, he had secretly aided several friends in distress, yet none knew it was he who had helped them. He could not bear to see others wronged and would quietly intervene. But for others—even close relatives—if they held power and were strangers to him, he would not trouble them with so much as a word.

When his supplies ran low and he urgently needed medicine, he would ask friends for help, accepting without refusal. Any assistance he received, he repaid gradually, ensuring the giver never noticed. If the aid did not come from a friend, he would not accept it. When his provisions lasted ten days, he would share them to relieve others’ needs, but if his own stores were insufficient, he would not deprive himself. He did not strive for petty displays of virtue or meticulous scruples. Among villagers, those deemed "good and kind" would sometimes bring wine and dishes to visit him. Though he did not consider them his equals, he did not refuse them. If he later repaid the gesture, he did not do so immediately.

Though his clan’s disciples and younger kin might deem such a stance too lenient, he would assign them both praise and blame without distinction. Some mocked him for this, to which he replied: “My person belongs to me. The principle should be easy to grasp. Suppose someone asked me to compare myself to the ancients or to my contemporaries, forcing me to rank myself—truly, I could not know with whom I might be matched. How much less should I presume to judge those who are not myself?

In the late Han, the corruption of custom gave rise to factions and cliques. Men like Xu Shao and his ilk wielded their tongues to issue warnings and engage in disputes, turning debates into feuds. Thus, the scholars of Runan had no fixed reputations, only the monthly evaluations of character. Even Emperor Wu of Wei deeply despised this and sought to behead them, driving them to flee in panic, nearly to the point of annihilation. The lesson lies close at hand—one may well take it as a teacher.

Moreover, people are not easily known. Even fathers and elder brothers may not fully understand their sons and younger brothers. Is what aligns with me necessarily right? Is what differs from me necessarily wrong? Some begin well but end poorly. Yao, the Duke of Zhou, Confucius, and Jizha all lamented their own incompleteness. How can those of us with narrow, flickering candlelight vision presume to judge others and assess their worth? Do we surpass those sagely and virtuous ancients?

During the Da’an era, Shi Bing rebelled, ravaging six provinces. Villages and towns were laid waste, and the righteous cause was overturned. The Grand Marshal of the Righteous Army summoned Hong to serve as a general and captain. Repeatedly pressed, and fearing deep calamity would befall his homeland, he recalled the ancient principle of aiding those in dire peril. Yet he also dreaded military discipline and dared not act on his own will. Thus, he recruited several hundred men and joined the army in its advance. Once, they attacked a separate rebel force and routed them. On that day, coins and silks piled like mountains, and treasures covered the ground. The other armies all released their soldiers to gather spoils, their carts and packs stretching end to end. Hong alone ordered his troops not to stray from formation. If any soldier was found looting, Hong immediately executed him as an example. Thus, none dared abandon their posts. Later, when hundreds of ambushers emerged to strike the other armies, those forces had scattered, their men and horses burdened with plunder, their fighting spirit gone. They fell into chaos, suffering heavy casualties, nearly beyond recovery. Only Hong’s troops remained orderly, their carts and tents undamaged, saving the other armies from total collapse. Hong’s merit was great in this.

In a later battle, he slew a minor rebel chieftain and captured many suits of armor and heads, presenting them as trophies to headquarters. The Grand Marshal then bestowed upon Hong the title of General Fubo, along with a gift of a hundred bolts of cloth, following standard practice. Many officers sealed their rewards or sent them home, but Hong distributed his among his officers and soldiers, as well as to impoverished acquaintances. Of the hundred bolts, he kept only ten for himself, then immediately used them to buy meat and wine to feast his officers and men. For a time, this became the talk of the day.

When the conflict ended, Hong cast aside his weapons and armor and headed straight for Luoyang, seeking to expand his collection of rare books. He made no mention of his military achievements, secretly admiring the principle of Lu Lian, who refused gold from Liaocheng, and Wu Zixu, who declined rewards for preserving Chu—embracing the virtue of not dwelling on success.

Just then, the capital fell into great turmoil, and the northern roads were blocked. Chen Min rebelled in Jiangdong, cutting off the return route. An old friend, Dong Ju, who had been appointed Governor of Guangzhou, submitted a memorial requesting Hong as his adjutant. Though the post was not to his liking, the south offered a refuge, so he reluctantly accepted. Sent ahead to muster troops, he waited for Dong Ju to follow, but Dong was killed en route. Hong thus remained in Guangzhou, frequently invited by regional commanders to serve, but he declined every offer.

He reflected: wealth and honor may be gradually attained but cannot be seized all at once. The pursuit of such things is wearisome and enough to exhaust a person. Moreover, glory and power are like lodgers—neither permanent nor something one can cling to. What rises high will inevitably fall; what blazes bright will fade. Like spring blossoms, they must wither. To rejoice in gaining them or grieve in losing them is to invite endless regret, sorrow, and fear—struggles too numerous to name. They are not worth the trouble.

Assessing his own nature, he found it deeply indolent, his talents severely limited. Even if he were to bow and scrape, rushing about in the dust, he would surely fail to achieve great fame or avoid entanglements—how much more so given his inability? Better to cultivate the Way of Master Red Pine and Wang Qiao, which lies within oneself and does not depend on others.

He aspired to ascend famous mountains, practice dietary arts, and nurture his nature—not out of neglect for worldly affairs, but because one cannot serve both at once. If he did not abandon worldly duties, how could he cultivate tranquility and the profound?

Moreover, true understanding is difficult and cannot be borrowed through inquiry or discussion. Thus, his carriage and horses never entered the domains of the powerful, and not a single word of his writing was exchanged with those in office. Though he could not entirely withdraw from the scholar’s circle, he refused to receive visitors. When others’ works infringed upon his own, he could not maintain his focus. He sighed: “There is no Dao in the mountains and forests.” Yet the ancients who cultivated the Dao invariably entered the mountains and forests, truly seeking to distance themselves from clamor and prevent their minds from being disturbed.

Now, he would fulfill his original aspiration: leaving his homeland, he would journey to Mount Song to seek the path of Fangping and Liang Gong. His earlier work, the *Master’s Book*, in both inner and outer chapters, had fortunately already been completed. He would now compile and arrange it to show to future generations.

At fifteen or sixteen, he had written poems, rhapsodies, and miscellaneous essays, which he then believed were passable. By the time he reached twenty, he reviewed them again and found much unsatisfactory. His talent had not necessarily improved—only his reading had broadened, and he now discerned the difference between the refined and the coarse. Thus, he discarded most of his earlier work, keeping less than one-tenth. Excluding the *Master’s Book*, he still had over a hundred scrolls of miscellaneous writings, though many remained unrevised, filled with sorrow and indignation, and he lacked the leisure to refine them further.

Others wrote swiftly, finding satisfaction in their work as soon as it was done. But his own talent was dull, his thoughts slow, and he could not produce polished prose on demand. Each time he revised a character, the text improved, but his laziness and the volume of his work prevented frequent review.

In his twenties, he had calculated that writing minor, trivial pieces wasted time better spent establishing a coherent philosophy. Thus, he began drafting the *Master’s Book*. However, war and upheaval scattered him, and some works were lost. For over a decade on the road, he did not take up his brush. Only in the Jianwu era did he finally settle, completing twenty inner chapters and fifty outer chapters, along with a hundred scrolls of stele inscriptions, eulogies, poems, and rhapsodies. He also wrote thirty scrolls of military documents, proclamations, letters, and memorials. Additionally, he compiled works not included in common catalogs: the *Biographies of Divine Immortals* in ten scrolls, the *Biographies of Recluses* in ten scrolls, and an anthology of essential passages from the Five Classics, the Seven Histories, the Hundred Schools, military affairs, techniques, and miscellaneous wonders, totaling three hundred and ten scrolls, each with its own catalog.

The inner chapters discuss matters of Daoist concern: divine immortals, elixirs, strange transformations, life-nourishing practices, longevity techniques, and methods to ward off misfortune. The outer chapters address Confucian themes: human successes and failures, and the right and wrong of worldly affairs.

Hong noted that Emperor Wen of Wei’s *Canon of Classics* omitted mention of games like tanqi and swordplay. He intended to briefly record what he knew, but in truth, his skills were few and minor, and he could not boast falsely. Now, he would fully describe what he had not yet mastered.

Ge Hong’s nature was dull and his talents mediocre. From the time his hair was first tied up in childhood, he lagged behind other boys in tossing tiles or wrestling. He never fought cocks, raced dogs or horses, and when he saw others gambling, he paid no heed. Even when dragged along to watch, he remained utterly disengaged, as if dozing in broad daylight. To this day, he does not know how many lines are on a chessboard or the names of the dice in *chupu*. He considers such pastimes trivial arts that scatter the mind and waste time. For officials, they harm governance; for scholars, they disrupt recitation; for commoners, they cause neglect of farming; for merchants, they lead to loss of goods. Before the outcome is decided, players grow heated in dispute, their faces flushed with anger, calling this "amusement" when in truth it is torment. It erodes integrity, sparks contention, invites heavy wagers, and breeds hidden grudges. In the past, Duke Min of Song and the Crown Prince of Wu met with fatal disasters, while the rebellion of the Seven States nearly toppled the imperial court—lessons bright as mirrors for a hundred generations. Whenever he observed players, he saw them flushed with shame and rage, striking out with hands and feet, hurling insults, severing friendships, and breaking ties—all too common. Resentment does not depend on scale; whether great or small, it often brings regret. Such pursuits are not worth the trouble.

Confucius warned against dozing in the daytime, but compared to Ge Hong, even that seems preferable. Daytime dozing is merely unproductive, whereas it does not risk resentment or litigation. The sage still wore out bamboo strips three times in his devotion to the classics—how could an ordinary man of modest talent manage both? All such games are inferior to even a foot of books. Thus, he naturally disliked them and never engaged, though such pastimes are dear to the common crowd.

In his youth, he once studied archery, but his strength was insufficient to draw a strong bow—only one like Yan Gao’s. He believed archery was among the Six Arts and could be used to repel bandits, resist raids, and hunt birds and beasts, so he practiced it. Once, while in the military, he shot at pursuing cavalry, striking down two enemies and a horse, thereby escaping death. He also learned the use of the shield and single- and double-edged swords, all with oral formulas and essential techniques for subduing opponents. There were even secret methods so skillful they seemed divine. When facing the untrained, he could single-handedly prevail, advancing without hindrance.

Later, he learned the seven-foot staff technique, which could be used to disarm opponents or break through defenses. Yet this, too, was a non-essential skill—knowing it was like possessing the horn of a qilin or the spur of a phoenix: what need was there for it? Few in his time understood such things.

From a young age, Ge Hong had a steadfast resolve never to enter officialdom. Whenever he read the biographies of Chao Fu, Xu You, the northern recluse of Zizhou, the two Jiangs of Shihu, the two Xiaos, Fazhen, and Zilong, he would set aside his books and lean forward in admiration. He aspired to master the Five Classics and compose a work of his own, so that later generations would know him as a literary scholar. Later, when the prefecture and the General of Chariots and Cavalry summoned him, he declined. Though recommended to the prime minister’s office of the Prince of Langye, when the uprising began and the rebels were pacified, he did not seek recognition or visit the office to claim merit. The officials in charge never rewarded his contributions.

He hoped that the King of Jin, who answered Heaven’s call and followed the people’s will, would restore order, revive the fading imperial lineage, repair the neglected ancestral temples, and honor the unrecognized merits of the previous dynasty to encourage future service. Ge Hong followed the general amnesty and, in the year *gengyin*, received an edict granting him the title of Marquis of Guanzhong, with a fief of two hundred households in Jurong. He had secretly led troops to suppress rebels and save his homeland, but his efforts were deemed insufficient for record. The honor of golden and purple seals was not his original aspiration. He had wished to emulate Lu Lian from afar and Tian Chou more closely, submitting petitions to decline and fulfill his reclusive ambitions. However, a general amnesty was in place, and his request was not granted.

In the past, Zhong You declined a reward he was due, yet this discouraged others from doing good. The barbarians had not yet been pacified, the realm was troubled, and the state sought to clarify rewards and punishments to uphold the law. How could a humble man like himself stubbornly cling to his timid resolve and resist the grand, all-encompassing system? Thus, he set aside his personal inclinations and respectfully accepted the imperial decree.

After Ge Hong wrote his autobiographical essay, someone challenged him, saying: "In his later years, Wang Chong feared his name and deeds would perish, so he wrote an account of himself. You, however, are in the prime of life, living in an era of sagely rule. You should be untying the silk bundles of Shen Gong and mounting the rush mats of Mei Sheng, illuminating the Nine Five with your brilliance and surpassing the fame of Kunwu. Why instead pursue the path of an old scholar, wasting your fragrance?"

Ge Hong replied: "Heaven and Earth stretch vast, yet man dwells as if in a borrowed abode. The morning mushroom’s brief bloom withers before the day is done; the spring flower’s glory fades within ten days. Even the fleeting flight of the whirlwind or the sudden flash of lightning are not necessarily swifter. The span of a hundred years is like a shooting star’s swift passage; gray hair flies by like an arrow through a gap. How much more so for those who wither in summer’s heat or perish before autumn’s chill? Thus, Xiangzi lamented the unharvested grain, and Yang Xiong mourned his early death.

"Looking back through the ages, extraordinary men have risen like dragons through literary arts or crouched like tigers through martial deeds. Their great merits are recorded in the bright halls, their virtuous reputations echoing through the bamboo and silk. Though their forms may decay in the earth, their fine reputations soar with the days. Even after a thousand or ten thousand generations, they remain revered.

"I, however, am mediocre and obscure, my steps out of sync with the times, my voice discordant with the world. My steps clash with the crowd, and within, I lack the support of the Jin or Zhang families; without, I have no friends to dust off their hats for me. Though the path may be smooth, my feet are not those of a *qilin*; though the skies may be vast, my wings are not those of the great peng. Above, I cannot soar like a hawk to aid the state; below, I cannot glorify my parents or leave behind a name. My virtues are not entrusted to good historians, nor is my fame inscribed on bells and tripods. Thus, in the margins of my writings, I have composed this autobiographical essay. Though it may not alter my fate, I rely on future generations to carry on the record."

*Baopuzi, Outer Chapters, Scroll Four*

chunks.translated_text:
From the *Imperially Commissioned Complete Library of the Four Treasuries*, *Baopuzi Inner Chapters*, Scroll Two, by Ge Hong of the Jin Dynasty, "Resolving Difficulties," Chapter Seven

Someone asked: The august heavens are supremely divine, bestowing fate with perfect impartiality—why then do pine and cypress, mere commoners, receive the gift of deathless longevity, while the great sages Zhou and Kong enjoy no enduring span of life?

Baopuzi replied: The length or brevity of life is truly determined by the celestial configurations one encounters at the moment of conception, when qi coalesces and the embryo forms. The Dao of Heaven acts without deliberate action, allowing things to follow their natural course—it shows no partiality, no favor, no distinction between this and that. If one’s fate is bound to the star of life, that person will inevitably be drawn to the Dao of immortality; those drawn to the Dao of immortality will, if they seek it, surely attain it. If one’s fate is bound to the star of death, that person will not believe in the Dao of immortality and will not cultivate its practices. Whether one delights in goodness or not is decided by what one is endowed with; alteration, bestowal, or deprivation are not within Heaven’s power. It is like gold and iron being smelted in the furnace or pottery and tiles being shaped in the kiln: though the furnace and kiln bring them into form, the sharpness or dullness of tools, the uprightness or crookedness of jars, depend on what they encounter—this is no longer the work of the furnace or kiln.

The questioner objected: All that a skilled craftsman creates comes from his own hands. How can the divine intelligence of Heaven be incapable of anything? Yet you claim that human lives each encounter their own configurations, and are not shaped by the vast azure. This I find deeply perplexing—I cannot assent to it.

Baopuzi answered: When the primordial chaos split and the clear and turbid separated, some rose and moved, others descended and stilled—even Heaven and Earth do not know why this is so. The myriad things respond to qi, each following its own nature, and together with Heaven and Earth, each becomes a distinct entity. The only difference lies in their sequence of formation and the scale of their bodies. Because Heaven and Earth are vast, we perceive the myriad things as small; because the myriad things are small, we perceive Heaven and Earth as vast. Moreover, though the abdomen and back enclose the five viscera, they do not create them; though skin and flesh envelop blood and qi, they do not produce them. Though Heaven and Earth contain the myriad things, they do not bring them into being. It is like grasses and trees relying on mountains and forests to sprout and flourish, yet the mountains and forests do not act upon them; fish and turtles depending on lakes and marshes to propagate, yet the lakes and marshes do not intervene. The common folk, seeing the vastness of Heaven and Earth and the smallness of the myriad things, say that Heaven and Earth are the parents of the myriad things, and the myriad things are their descendants. Yet the lice born upon me—did I create them? Thus, though lice cannot arise without me, I am not their parent, nor are they my descendants. Gnats breed in vinegar, lingzhi and glutinous rice grow on trees and rocks, beetles thrive in filth and sludge, and emerald vines flourish on pine branches—none of these four are crafted by those things. The myriad things teem within Heaven and Earth—how is this different?

Behold! Heaven possesses the sun and moon, the cycles of cold and heat; man possesses sight and hearing, breath and movement. By drawing distant analogies and extending near observations, one infers from this to that. Man cannot comprehend his own body—why he ages or grows young, why he feels pain or itches—just as Heaven cannot comprehend its own body, the reasons for its waxing and waning, its calamities and auspices. Man cannot ensure his ears and eyes remain ever sharp, his nourishing and defending *qi* unceasing; thus, Heaven cannot ensure the sun and moon avoid eclipses or the four seasons maintain their order. From this reasoning, matters of premature death or longevity truly do not lie with Heaven and Earth, nor are the secrets of immortality their doing.

That which gives me life is my father; that which bears me is my mother. Yet even they cannot guarantee my form will be perfectly proportioned, my countenance fair and lovely, my nature and principles balanced and harmonious, my wisdom lofty and far-reaching. They cannot multiply my strength, prolong my years, or extend my lifespan. Instead, some are stunted and frail, some dark and ugly; some are deaf, blind, stubborn, or perverse; some are crippled, toiling, or lame. What they obtain is not what they desire; what they desire is not what they obtain. How much less can Heaven and Earth, so vast and distant, achieve this? Even parents are far removed—how can I, possessing this body, ensure it remains forever robust and unaging, perpetually healthy and free from illness, its joy and anger never misplaced, its plans and reflections without regret or remorse? Thus, those who bestow *qi* and shape form are my parents; those who receive and possess them are my own body. Beyond these, nothing is more intimately connected, nothing exerts greater control. If even these two cannot alter or benefit me, how can Heaven and Earth claim any part in it?

If all beings were truly the creations of Heaven and Earth, they should all be good without evil, complete without flaw, and all living things should fulfill their destinies without the sorrow of spring’s fading or autumn’s decay. Yet Heaven cannot grant Confucius or Mencius the blessing of transcending the world, proving that what they received was natural, not apportioned by Heaven and Earth. Sagehood is the pinnacle of virtue; if Heaven could bestow such perfect virtue, why would it not allow their desires to be fully realized, their achievements established, their positions supreme, their lifespans exceeding a century? This is no proof of Heaven’s deliberate action. The death of a sage is not Heaven’s killing, just as the birth of a sage is not Heaven’s creation. The worthy are not necessarily long-lived, nor are the foolish doomed to die young; goodness does not always bring fortune, nor does evil always invite disaster. Birth has no fixed term, death no constant measure. Men of towering virtue and wisdom may wither unfulfilled, while the mediocre Dou Gong lived to two hundred; Bo Niu was stricken with illness, Zixia lost his sight; the villainous Robber Zhi lived to a white-haired old age, while the wicked Zhuang Qiao sported a head of yellow hair. In this, Heaven’s non-action is manifest.

Some say, Confucius declared, "Since ancient times, all must die," while Laozi spoke of the learnability of divine transcendence. The words of sages are trustworthy and verifiable, but the teachings of Daoists are fanciful and difficult to apply. The *Baopuzi* states: Confucius is the sage of the Confucians, Laozi the sage of the Dao. Confucian teachings are near and easy to perceive, hence many follow them; the intent of the Dao is distant and hard to grasp, hence few attain it. The Dao is the source of the ten thousand differences; Confucianism is but a stream of the great purity. Before the Three Sovereigns, the Dao governed; since the rise of emperors and kings, Confucianism has prevailed. Discussants all know to esteem the simplicity of high antiquity and disdain the decadence of later ages—why then do they revere Confucius while belittling Laozi? This is like admiring the blossoms at the tips of branches while failing to recognize the root from which they grow. How is this different from prizing luminous pearls while despising the deep pools, cherishing the *He* jade while loathing Mount Jing? They do not know that the deep pools are the source of luminous pearls, and Mount Jing the origin of the *He* jade.

Moreover, nurturing one’s nature is but a remnant of the Dao; ordering the world is but a minor aspect of Confucianism.

Thus, the value of Confucianism lies in its power to transform customs and reform manners—not merely in its rites of bowing and yielding or its measured steps. The reverence for the Dao rests in its silent transformation, its influence extending far beyond the single matter of nurturing life.

If Confucianism and the Dao truly had an order of precedence, then Confucius could not be exclusively trusted, nor could Laozi be employed in isolation. Confucius himself paid respectful homage to Boyang, wishing to be compared to Lao Peng, and admitted that while he understood the ways of fish and birds, he did not comprehend the dragon—a metaphor by which he acknowledged Laozi as the dragon, an expression of heartfelt admiration, not empty words. This is no different from his words to Yan Hui: *"Gazing at it, it appears ahead; suddenly, it is behind. Boring into it, it grows ever harder; looking up to it, it grows ever higher."*

Some ask: *"Confucius personally met Laozi yet did not follow his teachings—why?"* The *Baopuzi* replies: *"This makes it all the clearer that what one is endowed with is a mandate of nature, and what one esteems is an unchanging disposition. Confucius recognized the profound subtlety of Laozi’s teachings and valued their rarity, yet he could not draw from the wellspring of pure emptiness at its source. The Great Ancestor emerges beyond form and enters within the Perfect Dao. What he sought to learn was confined to matters of the common world—how could he have entreated the methods of immortality? His heart was wholly absorbed in teaching and transformation, with no thought for esoteric arts. Though sagely in worldly affairs, Confucius was not one to abide in stillness, profound silence, self-preservation, or non-action. Thus, Laozi admonished him: *'A good merchant hides his treasures as if empty; a noble man of great virtue appears foolish. Shed your pride, your excess of desires, your overbearing demeanor, your reckless ambitions—these bring no benefit to your person.'* From this, we may know that Confucius was not free from worldly attachments and was no practitioner of immortality’s Way.

Ever restless, ever anxious, his sole concern was to set the age aright—lamenting the phoenix’s silence above, sighing over the gourd’s unsold fate below. How could one so impassioned in his desire to wield the whip of governance abandon the work of ordering the world to pursue the roundabout path of nurturing life?"

Some ask: *"Between the endeavors of Confucianism and the Dao, which is more difficult, which easier?"* The *Baopuzi* answers: *"Confucianism is difficulty within ease; the Dao is ease within difficulty. To renounce social ties, forsake wife and children, reject fame and honor, forgo profit and rank, turn from the dazzling before one’s eyes, and silence the clamor in one’s ears—to remain serene and withdrawn, content in solitude, guarding one’s integrity, unmoved by slander, unelated by praise, indifferent to high station, unashamed of lowly estate—this is the difficulty of the Dao. Yet one need not attend to condolences or visits, bear no burden of care for others, exhaust neither mind in the Seven Classics nor thought in calculations and calendrics, suffer no toil of astrological reckoning, nor servitude to literary arts. Freed from the weight of worldly burdens, harmony naturally flourishes; in non-action and non-concern, one knows no fear or dread—this is the ease of the Dao. Thus, it is ease within difficulty.

The Confucian, by contrast, follows established laws and models, his conduct governed by rules, his speech and silence timed to the moment, his teachers found in every household, his books clarified by commentaries and annotations—this is the ease of Confucianism. Yet to probe the profound and reach the distant, to weave together the ancient canons, to master the *He* and *Luo* texts, to encompass the vast learning of the Hundred Schools, to cultivate virtue in humble lanes, to devote one’s resolve to serving the ruler, to strain one’s spirit toward celestial patterns, to apply one’s thought to wind and clouds—if one matter remains unknown, one’s work is incomplete; if a single word is amiss, praise and blame are misapplied. Every step becomes a model for the world; every utterance is transmitted across the land—this is the difficulty of Confucianism. Thus, it is difficulty within ease.

Weighing the two, the Confucian path is largely difficult, while the Daoist way is succinct and easy. I have already suffered its difficulties—why not abandon it and follow what is easy? Yet those who mock me in this world are as numerous as shoulder-to-shoulder crowds, while those who share my aspirations remain unseen. If like-minded souls exist, they must belong to a future age—for I do not consider them rare.

Some say: *'Among the eminent scholars and erudite masters I have encountered—those who have plumbed principles to their depths, exhausted the nature of things, and scrutinized the boundaries of being and non-being—many have there been. Yet none have spoken of extending life or attaining immortality. Though your brilliance may rival the sun and moon, and your thoughts surpass ten thousand men, you suddenly discourse on the Way of long life—how can I believe it?'* The *Baopuzi* replies: *'Am I a man of mediocre talent, shallow insight, and scant learning, who would dare claim unique understanding surpassing all others? Yet have I not sought what is manifest and found it in the obscure? Have I not obtained with ease what others deem difficult?'* "

Those who dispute minor proofs will recognize their greater efficacy; those who witness what has already come to pass will understand what has yet to be tested.

Moreover, those who disbelieve in the existence of immortals in this world generally possess only the talents of common scholars, the skills of officeholders, or the knowledge gleaned from books that aid instruction. They judge human affairs by what is near and easily discerned, and when confronted with the vulgar delusions of the multitude, they claim: *"What others doubt, I alone can decide; what has not yet shown its first signs, I can foresee."* Thus, they believe they have exhausted the nature of all things, penetrated all that is hidden and obscure, and obtained all that can be known. If I say there are no immortals, then immortals must not exist—so firmly entrenched is this conviction.

I have often observed mediocre scholars who stubbornly reject and disbelieve in such matters. Their failing lies in possessing some intelligence yet being crippled by partiality and constraint, shackled by their own limitations, unwilling to consider what lies beyond. They are utterly benighted, unable to distinguish beans from wheat. To use the narrow vision of a pipe to block what their own intelligence cannot grasp—how is this different from using a single-rope well bucket to draw water from a hundred-fathom depth, then blaming the well for having no water when they fail to recognize the inadequacy of their tool?

Those who observe form place unwavering trust in their own eyes—yet when what they hear and see is affirmed as true but proves false, are their ears and eyes truly beyond doubt? How much more so with the mind’s conjectures, which discern neither form nor sound, and whose obscurity far exceeds that of sight and hearing. Truth and falsehood have their essence, yet inclinations and aversions clash, so the two hearts do not counsel one another. There are those who take the ugly for the beautiful, the turbid for the clear, the loss for the gain—these three divergences are glaringly evident, so plain to see. To wait for the common folk to cease their reckless talk is to wait for the Yellow River to run clear—it would not be long by comparison. To see a dragon and call it a snake is not because the dragon lacks numinosity, but because only Cai Mo can distinguish it. The reason the Dao is prized is that it cannot be increased by addition nor diminished by subtraction. The reason virtue is prized is that one hears slander without gloom and sees praise without delight. Those who firmly believe the world has no immortals, while I alone contend that they truly exist—this dispute grows ever more protracted, and their obstinacy ever more entrenched. Is this not a futile prolongation of this endless strife, offering no remedy for their incomprehension? Should one truly follow the principle of the interlocking rings?

*Releasing Doubts*, Chapter Eight

Someone asked: The ways of humanity are manifold, and seeking immortality is supremely difficult. If one does not abandon worldly affairs, how can one simultaneously attend to literary arts, the concerns of sorrow and joy, and the Way of ruler and minister?

The *Baopuzi* replied: The Dao is not burdensome; what is rare is the few who act upon it. The only concern is whether one’s resolve is firmly established and one’s faith unwavering—why fear the neglect of human affairs? Those of great talent can cultivate both without difficulty. They inwardly treasure the Way of nurturing life and outwardly harmonize with the world. In governing the self, they achieve long cultivation; in governing the state, they bring great peace. They use the Six Classics to instruct the common people and transmit esoteric arts to those of like mind. If they wish to remain briefly, they stay to assist the times; if they wish to ascend, they soar into the clouds and lightly depart—these are the superior scholars. Those who rely on their own abilities but cannot achieve both may set aside worldly affairs and focus solely on cultivating the Dao—these are the next best. In ancient times, the Yellow Emperor bore the burden of the Four Seas yet did not hinder his ascent at Mount Dinghu. Peng Zu served as a grandee for eight hundred years before traveling west to the Flowing Sands. Boyang was a chronicler, Maofeng a potter, Fang Hui a scholar, Lü Wang a grand preceptor, Qiu Sheng served in Yin, Ma Tui was an official in Jin, Lord Fan conquered Yue and sailed the seas, Qin Gao held a tablet in Song, Kang Changsheng humbled himself to hold the whip, and Duke Zhuang concealed his talents as a minor scribe. Many ancients attained the Dao while aiding the world, cultivating it in court and market—surely they had surplus energy. Why must one retreat to the mountains and forests, completely abandoning the affairs of the people, before achieving success?

There are also those whose hearts find peace in stillness, whose natures abhor clamor, who delight in freedom and loathe honor and office. They wear coarse ropes and tattered clothes, eat wild herbs, hold the plow, and enjoy their three joys. They abide by constancy, await their end, do not scheme for a fleeting life, and do not fear swift death. They decline appointments worth a thousand gold and scorn the nobility of high ministers. Even without cultivation, they are already like this—how much less would they be willing to serve the world if they were to add the supreme Dao to their practice? Each follows their own aspirations; one cannot generalize.

The *Baopuzi* said: The world says that a single good word is worth a thousand gold—yet this refers only to the gains and losses of state or the right and wrong of personal conduct. As for teaching others the secret of long life or transmitting the method of immortality, this is not merely a good word like those of ordinary people. How could it be worth only a thousand gold? If someone on the verge of death from illness could be saved and restored to health, none would fail to call it a profound kindness and a great favor. Now, if one follows the immortal classics and ingests the Nine Elixirs of liquid gold and jade, the entire world could be made immortal—its beneficence would not be merely the merit of saving one person. The virtue of the Yellow Emperor and Laozi is truly immeasurable, yet none recognize it, dismissing it as absurd and preposterous—how lamentable!

The *Baopuzi* said: To seek immortality, one must grasp its essentials. The essentials lie in treasuring essence, practicing qi, and ingesting the great elixir—this is sufficient, and no more is needed. Yet these three matters again have shallow and deep levels. Without a named teacher or enduring hardship, one cannot master them hastily. Though it is said to practice qi, there are several methods of doing so. Though it is said to practice the bedchamber arts, there are nearly a hundred techniques therein. Though it is said to ingest elixirs, there are roughly a thousand formulas for doing so. When first teaching others, one begins with the shallow. Only when their resolve is unwavering and their diligence evident does one reveal the deeper methods.

Thus, practicing qi can cure a hundred illnesses, enter epidemics, subdue tigers and snakes, stanch wounds and bleeding, allow one to dwell in water or walk upon it, ward off hunger and thirst, or extend lifespan. Its great essential is embryonic breathing. Those who attain embryonic breathing can refrain from exhaling and inhaling through the nose and mouth, as if within the womb—then the Dao is achieved. When first learning to practice qi, one draws qi through the nose and holds it, silently counting to one hundred twenty before gently exhaling through the mouth. Both inhalation and exhalation should be inaudible to oneself. One should always inhale more and exhale less. A test is to place a goose feather on the nose and mouth—if the feather does not move when exhaling, this is the sign. Gradually increase the count over time, and eventually one can reach a thousand. At a thousand, the old become young again, and one day’s practice reverses a day’s aging.

One should practice qi during the time of living qi, not during the time of dead qi. Thus it is said: "The immortal ingests the six qi." In a day and night, there are twelve hours. From midnight to noon are the six hours of living qi; from noon to midnight are the six hours of dead qi. Practicing qi during dead qi is of no benefit. Those who use qi can exhale upon water, causing it to flow backward for several paces; exhale upon fire, causing it to extinguish; exhale upon tigers and wolves, causing them to crouch and be unable to move; exhale upon snakes and vipers, causing them to coil and be unable to depart. If another is wounded by blades or weapons, exhaling upon them stanches the blood. If one hears of someone struck by poison, even if unseen, one can exhale from afar, directing the breath—men exhale upon their left hand, women upon their right—and though the person may be a hundred miles away, they will immediately recover. For sudden afflictions or acute illnesses, merely swallowing the qi of three nines also brings instant relief. Yet human nature is often restless, and few can remain tranquil to cultivate this Way.

Moreover, in practicing qi, one should not eat too much raw vegetables or rich, fresh foods, as they make the qi strong and difficult to contain. One must also refrain from anger, for much anger disorders the qi, preventing its overflow and sometimes causing coughing—thus few can succeed in this practice. My great-grandfather, the Immortal Duke, whenever deeply drunk or in the height of summer’s heat, would enter the depths of deep pools and remain for a day before emerging—this was precisely because he could close his breath and practice embryonic breathing.

The bedchamber arts comprise over ten schools: some repair injuries and damages, some attack and cure various illnesses, some gather yin to replenish yang, and some increase years and extend life. Their great essential lies in the single matter of returning essence to replenish the brain.

This method is one passed down orally from one true adept to another, never committed to writing. Even if one consumes famous medicines yet remains ignorant of this essential teaching, one still cannot attain longevity. Moreover, one must not completely abstain from the union of yin and yang, for doing so leads to stagnation and obstruction, giving rise to pent-up resentment, loneliness, illness, and shortened life. Yet yielding to unbridled desire also diminishes one’s years and vitality. Only by attaining the harmony of regulated release can one avoid harm. Without the oral transmission of its techniques, not a single practitioner will fail to injure or even destroy themselves through this practice.

The likes of Xuansuzi, Rongchenggong, and Pengzu recorded only its coarse aspects, never committing its most essential teachings to paper. Those who aspire to immortality should diligently seek and practice it. I have recorded these words as I received them from my teacher, Master Zheng, to show future believers in the Dao—this is no groundless speculation. Yet I myself have not fully mastered its secrets.

Some Daoist practitioners of one narrow path may wish to focus solely on the arts of sexual union in pursuit of immortality, neglecting the great medicine of golden elixir—this is utter folly. As the *Baopuzi* states, the Daoist texts that derive from the Yellow Emperor and Laozi are but a small fraction. Most are the work of later enthusiasts, each adding their own interpretations, so that the volumes now pile up like mountains. The ancients were simple and often lacked literary talent; their discussions of natural principles were incomplete, their evidence unclear. They concealed their essential teachings, making them difficult to understand, and even when explained, the explanations were not profound enough to fully expound their meaning, open the way for the frustrated, encourage the determined, instruct beginners, or reveal the subtle paths of the mysterious and wondrous, the sources of fortune and misfortune. Merely reciting these texts ten thousand times will yield nothing. Even if one seeks broad learning, one should carefully select the finest works and focus on them, for texts that do not convey the essential Way are not worth poring over.

Some later learners fail to distinguish the depth of their authors. Taking anything labeled as Daoist teachings, they collect them indiscriminately until their boxes and baskets overflow, exhausting their minds in search of meaning—like seeking phoenix eggs in a swallow’s nest or trying to catch eels at the bottom of a well. No matter how diligent their efforts, they seek what cannot be found, gaining nothing of practical use. They waste their days and months in vain toil, reaping not even the slightest benefit. In public life, they fail in their duties; in private, they achieve no longevity. Thus, people inevitably point and say, “They practiced the Dao so diligently yet did not transcend the world—surely there is no method for avoiding death!” But they do not realize that such seekers of immortality are like those who stand by a river, admiring the fish but lacking a net—it is not that the water holds no fish.

The *Five Thousand Characters* may have come from Laozi, yet they are but general and cursory discussions. They never fully present a coherent method that can be verified. Merely reciting this scripture without grasping its essential Way is labor in vain—how much more so for those who fall short of even that?

As for Wenzi, Zhuangzi, Guanling Yinxin, and their like, though their florid writings trace back to the Yellow Emperor and Laozi, expounding the great principles of the mysterious and empty, they never reveal the ultimate teachings. Some even equate life and death, calling them no different, treating survival as forced labor and demise as rest—such views are already a thousand *li* removed from the path of immortality. How can they be worth indulging? Yet their allegories and parables may still offer some value for minor uses, filling gaps in times of need. Alas, that later generations of glib, unscrupulous, and immoral men have made Laozi and Zhuangzi their dens of refuge—is this not lamentable?

Some may ask: “In an age ruled by a sagely and enlightened sovereign who treasures only the worthy, if those who study immortality refuse to enter office and instead cultivate the Dao, who will assist in governance?” The *Baopuzi* replies: To turn one’s back on a sagely ruler and dwell in the mountains was why Chaofu and Xu You were esteemed. To encounter a virtuous age and withdraw from the world was why Zhuang Bo was honored. The Yellow Emperor ruled all under heaven in perfect order, yet Guangchengzi did not serve him. Tang Yao governed the four seas in great peace, yet Woquan did not assist him. Yet neither the transformative power of their virtue nor the supply of talented men suffered for it.

chunks.original_text: 天乙革命而务光负石以投河姬武剪商而夷齐不食于西山齐桓之兴而少稷高枕于陋巷魏文之隆而干木散发于衡门四老凤戢于商洛而不妨大汉之事功也 周党麟跱于林薮而无损孝文之刑厝也 夫宠贵不能动其心极富不能移其志濯缨沧浪不降不辱以芳林为台榭峻岫为大厦翠兰为茵褥绿叶为帏幙被褐代衮衣薇藿当嘉膳匪躬耕不以充饥匪妻织不以蔽身千载之中时或有之况又加之以委六亲于邦族捐室家而不顾背荣华如弃迹绝可欲于胸心凌嵩峻以独往侣影响于名山内视于无形之域反乎 至寂之中八极之内将遽防人而吾子乃恐君之无臣不亦多忧乎 或曰学仙之士独洁身而忘大伦之乱背世主而有不臣之慢余恐长生无成功而罪罟将见及也 抱朴子答曰夫北人石户善卷子州皆大才也 而沉遁放逸养其浩然升降不为之亏大化不为之缺也 况学仙之人未必有经国之才立朝之用得之不加尘露之益弃之不觉毫之损者乎 方今九有同宅而幽荒来仕元凯委积无所用之士有待次之滞官无暂旷之职勤久者有迟叙之叹才高者有循资之屈济济之盛莫此之美一介之徒非所乏也 昔子晋舍视膳之役弃储贰之重而灵王不责之以不孝尹生委襟带之职违式遏之任而有周不罪之以不忠何者彼诚亮其非轻世薄主直以所好者异匹夫之志有不可移故也 夫有道之主含垢善恕知人心之不可同处世之各有志不逼不禁以崇光大上无嫌恨之褊心下有称意之至欢故能晖声并扬于防极贪夫闻风而忸怩也 吾闻景风起则裘炉息世道夷则奇士退今丧乱既平休牛放马烽燧灭影干戈载戢繁弱既韬卢鹊将烹子房出帷而反闾巷信布释甲胄而修鱼钓况乎 学仙之士万未有一国家吝此以何为哉 然其事在于少思寡欲其业在于全身久寿非争竞之丑无伤俗之负亦何罪乎 且华霍之极大沧海之滉漾其高不俟翔埃之来其深不仰行潦之注撮壤土不足以减其峻挹勺水不足以削其广一世不过有数仙人何能有损人物之鞅掌乎 或曰果其仙道可求得者五经何以不载周孔何以不言圣人何以不度世上智何以不长存若周孔不知则不可为圣若知而不学则是无仙道也 抱朴子答曰人生星宿各有所值既详之于前篇矣 子可谓戴盆以仰望不睹七曜之炳灿暂引领于大川不知重渊之奇怪也 夫五经所不载者无限矣 周孔所不言者不少矣 特为吾子略说其万一焉 虽大笑不可止局情难卒开且令子闻其较略焉 夫天地为物之大者也 九圣共成易经足以弥纶阴阳不可复加也 今问善易者周天之度数四海之广狭宇宙之相去凡防万里上何所极下何所据及其转动谁所推引日月迟疾九道所剩昏明修短七星迭正五纬盈缩冠珥薄蚀四七凌犯慧孛所出气矢之异景老之祥辰极不动镇星犹东羲和外景而望舒内鉴而寒天汉仰上为润下之性涛潮往来有大小之变五音六属寓喜怒之情云动气起含吉凶之候欃枪尤矢旬始终绎四镇五残天狗归邪或以子成或以正败明易之生不能论此也 以次问春秋四部诗书三礼之家皆复无以对矣 皆曰悉正经所不载唯有巫咸甘公石申海中郄萌七曜记之悉矣

When Tang overthrew the Xia, Wu Guang bore a stone and cast himself into the river; when King Wu destroyed the Shang, Boyi and Shuqi refused to eat in the Western Mountains. When Duke Huan of Qi rose to power, Shao Ji reclined in a humble lane; when Wei Wen flourished, Gan Mu let his hair loose at his gate. The Four Elders withdrew to Shangluo, yet this did not hinder the great achievements of the Han; Zhou Dang stood aloof in the forests and marshes, yet this did no harm to the penal reforms of Emperor Wen. For such men, neither favor nor wealth could sway their hearts, nor could extreme riches alter their resolve. They washed their tassels in the Canglang’s waters, neither submitting nor suffering disgrace. They took fragrant groves as their pavilions, towering peaks as their mansions, emerald orchids as their cushions, green leaves as their curtains. They wore coarse cloth in place of court robes, ate wild greens instead of fine fare. Without tilling the soil themselves, they did not fill their bellies; without their wives’ weaving, they did not clothe their bodies. Such men have appeared from time to time over a thousand years—how much more so when they further abandon their kin to their clans, forsake their households without a glance, spurn glory as if it were dust, banish desire from their hearts, scale towering peaks alone, befriend echoes in the famed mountains, turn inward to the formless realm, and return to the utmost stillness? Within the eight directions, they guard against none, yet you fear the ruler will lack ministers—is this not excessive worry?

Some may say: “Those who study immortality merely purify themselves while neglecting the great bonds of society; they turn their backs on the sovereign and display disloyal disrespect. I fear they will fail to achieve long life and instead incur punishment.” The *Baopuzi* replies: The northerners Shi Hu and Shan Juan, along with Zizhou, were all men of great talent, yet they lived in seclusion, roamed freely, and nurtured their vast integrity. Neither the grand transformations of the age nor the great Way suffered loss for it. How much less should those who study immortality necessarily possess the talent to govern or the usefulness to stand in court? Gaining them would not add even a drop of dew’s benefit; losing them would not cause the slightest harm. Today, the nine provinces are united, and even those from distant lands come to serve. The virtuous and capable are abundant, yet there are idle officials awaiting posts and long-serving ones sighing over delayed promotions. Those of high talent chafe under seniority constraints. The flourishing of worthy men is unmatched—how could the realm lack even a single commoner?

In former times, Prince Jin abandoned his duty to attend the royal meals and relinquished his position as heir apparent, yet King Ling did not reproach him for disloyalty. Yin Sheng resigned his official sash and departed from his post, yet the Zhou did not condemn him for disloyalty. Why? They truly understood that such men did not slight the world or despise the ruler; their aspirations simply differed from those of ordinary men and could not be altered. A ruler of the Dao harbors tolerance and forgiveness, knowing that human hearts cannot be the same and that each person’s path in life differs. He does not compel or forbid, thereby honoring and magnifying the highest principles. Above, he bears no grudging narrowness; below, he enjoys the utmost joy of those who follow their hearts. Thus, his radiant reputation shines in all directions, and even the greedy, hearing of it, feel shame.

I have heard that when the balmy winds rise, fur robes and stoves are put away; when the world’s path is level, extraordinary men withdraw. Now that the ravages of war are settled, oxen are left to rest and horses released; beacon fires are extinguished, and the shadows of shields and spears are stilled. The mighty bows *Fanruo* and *Luque* are sheathed and cooked. Zhang Liang left the dark tent to return to the lanes; Xin Pi doffed his armor to take up fishing. How much more so for those who study immortality—of whom there is not even one in ten thousand—what harm could the state suffer in sparing them?

Yet their practice lies in few thoughts and scant desires; their work lies in preserving the body and prolonging life. They do not engage in the ugliness of competition nor bear the burden of offending custom—what crime is there in this? Moreover, the peaks of Hua and Heng are vast, the ocean’s expanse boundless. Their heights do not await the arrival of soaring dust; their depths do not rely on the inflow of rainwater. A handful of earth cannot diminish their loftiness; a ladle of water cannot lessen their breadth. In a generation, there are but a few immortals—how could they disrupt the world’s affairs?

Some may say: “If the Dao of immortality can truly be sought and attained, why do the Five Classics not record it? Why do Zhou and Confucius not speak of it? Why do the sages not transcend the world? Why do the supremely wise not live forever? If Zhou and Confucius did not know of it, they cannot be called sages; if they knew but did not study it, then there is no Dao of immortality.” The *Baopuzi* replies: Human lives correspond to the stars, each with its destined station—this has already been explained in the preceding chapter. You might as well wear a basin on your head and look up, failing to see the radiance of the seven luminaries, or briefly crane your neck toward a great river, unaware of the wonders in its depths.

There are countless things the Five Classics do not record; there are many matters Zhou and Confucius did not speak of. Let me briefly mention a fraction for you. Though you may laugh uncontrollably and your feelings may be hard to open, let me at least allow you to hear a rough outline.

Heaven and earth are the greatest of all things. The nine sages together composed the *Book of Changes*, which suffices to encompass yin and yang—nothing more can be added. Now, ask a master of the *Changes*: What are the degrees of the celestial sphere? How vast are the four seas? How far apart are the cosmos? Where does the upper limit end? Where does the lower limit rest? What propels their turning and movement? Why do the sun and moon vary in speed? What causes the nine paths’ excesses, the alternation of dawn and dusk, the lengthening and shortening of days? How do the seven stars take turns governing? How do the five planets wax and wane? What causes the halos, eclipses, conjunctions, and transgressions of the four and seven? Where do comets and broom stars emerge? What are the anomalies of celestial arrows and vapors? What are the omens of solar halos and old stars? Why does the pole star not move while the guardian star still drifts east? Why does the sun’s light extend beyond its form, while the moon’s light is cold within? Why does the Milky Way, when viewed from above, embody the nature of moisture flowing downward? Why do the tides ebb and flow with great and small variations? How do the five notes and six pitches convey emotions of joy and anger? How do clouds move and qi rise, bearing signs of fortune and misfortune? What are the *changqiang*, *you shi*, *xun*, and *shizhong*? What are the *sizhen* and *wucan*? What are the *tiangou* and *guixie*? Some bring success through the son, others ruin through the proper way. Even the *Changes* at its most profound cannot address these matters.

Next, ask the masters of the *Spring and Autumn*, the Four Books, the *Book of Songs*, and the Three Ritual Classics—none will be able to answer. They will all say: “These are entirely unrecorded in the orthodox classics; only Wu Xian, Gan Gong, Shi Shen, and Hai Zhong’s Xi Meng recorded them in the *Seven Luminaries*.”

chunks.original_text: 余将问之曰此六家之书是为经典之教乎 彼将曰非也 余又将问曰甘石之徒为是圣人乎 彼亦曰非也 然则人生而戴天诣老履地而求之于五经之上则无之索之于周孔之书则不得今宁可尽以为虚妄乎 天下至大举目所见犹不能了况于之又妙之极妙者乎 复问俗人曰夫乘云玺产之国肝心不朽之民巢居穴处独目三首马间狗蹄修臂交股黄池无男穿胸劳口廪居起石而况士船沙丘触目而生群龙女娲地出壮穿天堕甓飞大言【甓一作璧】山徙社移三军之众一朝尽化君子为鹤小人成沙女仞【一作丑】倚枯二负抱柱寄居之防委甲步内二首之蛇之为弓不灰之木不之火昌蜀之禽无目之兽无身之头无首之体精卫填海交让递生火浣之布切玉之刀炎昧吐烈磨泥漉水枯灌化形山防前跟石修九首毕方人少千之劾伯率圣卿之役肃霜西羌以唐景兴鲜卑以乘鳖强林邑以神录王庸蜀以流尸帝监神娶来而防飞纵目世变于荆岫五丁引蛇以倾峻内其振翅于三海金简玉字发于禹井之侧正机平衡割乎 文石之中凡此奇事盖以千计五经所不载周孔所不说可皆复云无是事乎 至于南人能入柱以出耳 御冦停肘水而控伯昏蹑亿仞而企踵吕梁能行歌以凭渊宋公刻楮叶以乱真公输飞木防之翩翻离朱觌毫芒于百步贲获效膂力于万钧越人揣针以苏死竖亥超迹于累千郢人奋斧于鼻垩仲都袒身于寒天此皆周孔所不能为也 复可以为无有乎 若圣人诚有所不能则无怪于不得仙不得仙亦无妨于为圣人圣人偶所不闲何足以为攻难之主哉 圣人或不可同去留任自然有身而不私有生而不营存亡任天长短委命故不学仙亦何怪也 道意第九 抱朴子曰道者涵干括坤其本无名论其无则影响犹为有焉 论其有则万物犹为无焉 首不能计其多少离朱不能察其仿髴吴札晋野竭聪不能防其音声乎 防之内狶猪疾走不能迹其朕兆乎 宇宙之外以言乎 迩则周流秋毫而有余焉 以言乎 远则弥纶太虚而不足焉
