Thus it serves to assist the six palaces in regulating yin and yang, to instruct and solemnify the ancestral temples, to serve the divine spirits, to uphold the great sacrifices, to don the dark-tasseled robes, and to broaden the paths of the royal lineage. Moreover, according to the *Records of the Nine Lands* in the Zhou canon and the geographical texts of the Han, the number of women in the realm exceeds that of men—how could the king’s consorts possibly crowd out those who ought to marry?

Duke Ji of Zhou pondered this and seemed to have considered it carefully. The emperor leads the hundred officials in the *jie-tian* ritual; the empress and consorts of noble rank oversee weaving. Extending to the common folk, farming duties are limited, tillage is rewarded, and idleness is punished. A tithe is levied to supply public needs, households maintain reserves for defense, and the state stores nine years’ worth of provisions. Each follows the natural division of labor, none is deprived of their season, taxes are light, corvée labor is sparse, and the people suffer neither hunger nor cold. When clothing and food are sufficient, rites and deference arise.

In the eras of Emperors Wen and Jing, the people devoted themselves to farming, households were well-provided, and granaries overflowed with grain—so much that the red husks rotted beyond counting. Yet even then, scholars and commoners still dined on fine meats and rode in carriages drawn by oxen and horses. This was because taxation was moderate and did not deplete the people. In later ages, officials abandoned the system of tillage quotas, and private pursuits turned to frivolous trades. The way of growing grain narrowed while idle mouths multiplied, so that both high and low alike transgressed, and offenders abounded.

Master Bao thus blamed the ruler, but it would be better to criticize the excesses of conscription and selection, to censure the unreliability of farming quotas, to rebuke the three thousand who drink like oxen, and to reduce the land tax to a third or half. If only the rear palace adhered to the Zhou rites and taxes were not levied arbitrarily, this would suffice. Must there truly be no ruler?

If the ruler rises late even once, affairs will fall into disorder. When entering the forest without a forester, even the deer will elude you—how can this be sustained indefinitely? Without a guiding authority, the noble lose their model, the people achieve their desires, and even a loose net still catches some fish. Can there be no net at all?

Master Bao said: “For people to live, clothing and food are already burdensome. If one further imposes heavy taxes and labor services, hunger and cold will converge, and the people will be unable to endure their fate, leading them to defy the law and commit crimes.”

The Master of Embracing Simplicity refuted this, saying: “The spider spins its web, yet fleas and lice do not starve. Human ingenuity harnesses the myriad things to feed mouths and clothe bodies—what hardship is there in this? The problem lies in the rich having no limit to their desires and the noble having boundless expenditures. How can one, for the sake of a single precaution, abandon governance entirely, fearing the cruelty of Jie and Zhou? To say there is taxation and labor service is to invite chaos—then I ask: in the age of peace under Yao and Shun, in the virtuous eras of the Three Dynasties, were there no taxes or labor services to support the ruler and ministers? Did the Son of Heaven and his officials plow the fields to sustain themselves?”

Master Bao then said: “The king treads as if over deep abysses and tiger tails, his peril beyond comparison. He sleeps lightly, rising before dawn, and eats only after the sun has declined—what cause has he to fear calamity?”

The Master of Embracing Simplicity countered: “If a ruler truly acts thus, he is a sage-king. The true affliction of kings lies in arrogance and extravagance, in failing to employ the worthy and employing the unworthy. King Jie of Xia pointed to the sun and swore he would not perish; the First Emperor of Qin feared sharing a posthumous name with others, yet both brought ruin upon themselves and became laughingstocks for posterity. If a ruler fears danger, remains vigilant at dusk, broadly accepts admonitions, consults even the humble, nurtures the aged, and seeks counsel from the venerable—what worry is there of misjudgment? What peril is there that the hundred affairs will not prosper? Diligence orders the constant norms; laxity breeds villainy. How much worse, then, if there is no ruler at all—could there be no chaos?”

Master Bao said: “The king covets rare omens and lures distant lands, seeking to exalt his virtue and magnify his might, dazzling the un-subdued. What benefit is there to the common people in white pheasants or jade rings?”

The Master of Embracing Simplicity refuted this, saying: “When the king’s virtue reaches Heaven, there are celestial portents; when it reaches Earth, there are terrestrial responses. The radiant star scatters its light to aid the moon’s glow; the solar halo displays its hues to mark the sun’s path. Divine birds sing in the palace towers; golden images gleam upon the clear pools—were these brought about by humble words or lavish gifts? Wang Mang, treacherous and harboring malice, fabricated signs of peace to deceive the court and the realm, even sending envoys to foreign lands to present auspicious omens. Can this be taken as proof that all ancient omens were the same?

Seeing a tail a fathom long, one knows the beast is not a handspan in size; observing fangs a cubit long, one knows the mouth is not an inch wide. Thus, the Queen Mother of the West sent envoys, proving her numinous transformation and boundless influence. The distant state of Yuechang, through repeated translations, came to offer tribute, showing that benevolence had reached even the remotest lands. Remote domains cannot be subdued by force; barbarians cannot be cowed by might. Without perfect governance, how could this be achieved?”

The wasp and scorpion bear venom to defend themselves; the clever bird carries reeds to shield against nets; the badger bends its burrow to guard against sudden assault; the water buffalo forms ranks to repel the ferocity of tigers and leopards. Yet Master Bao would cast aside armor and helmets to advance sharp blades, raze city walls to halt charging forces. If armor and helmets are discarded and sharp blades do not cease, if city walls are destroyed and charges still gather—even Gongshu Ban and Mo Di could not preserve themselves. How, then, shall our lives be secured?

Some say: “If there are no coveted goods, even without fortified walls, enemies will not come.” Master Baopu replies: “Must coveted goods be gold or jade, the point of an awl or knife? The foolish masses contend over them. The great war of the Yue people arose from the unequal division of a python’s flesh; the rebellion of Wu and Chu was sparked by a single mulberry leaf. In times of famine, men devour one another. Yet in the past, bare-handed and barefoot, from afar like Fu Hou and Zigao, from near like Yu Gong, they probed the truth, weighed punishments, split hairs and shaved grains. Those condemned to execution swallowed their voices and sang of virtue; those mutilated by amputation or nose-cutting bore no grudge to their dying day—all this occurred not in a time without rulers.

Long ago, when a widower dwelt in lowliness, the Four Peaks did not conceal him; when obscure worthies were sought, the finest talents were all raised. Some cast aside their butcher’s knives to enter the golden gates; some left their trowels and bricks to ascend jade halls; some abandoned their fodder and hay to become ministers and chancellors; some, fleeing for their lives, became supreme generals. Bo Liu avenged his foe; Xie Hu recommended his enemy; Fang Hui knocked his head to attract scholars; Qin Xi shattered his skull to advance the worthy. I ask: were these times without rulers?

It is further said: ‘Fields lie fallow, granaries stand empty—all because of rulers.’ But rulers are not the creeping weeds that choke the fields, nor are ministers the sparrows and rats that deplete the granaries. That fields lie fallow and granaries stand empty is ultimately due to calamitous fate—floods and droughts, epidemics and plagues—leading to famine and want. How can this be blamed on the levies and demands of governance?

Among the Eight Regulations, food is foremost, called the people’s Heaven. Hou Ji tilled the fields himself; the Yu sovereign plowed in person. In years of plenty, millet and rice abound; our granaries brim with grain. Canals are dug to drain alkaline soils, turning them into fertile fields. To know when to stop, to embrace sufficiency, and to dwell in emptiness—these are the calculations of preservation. Feasting in ease and abounding in fullness are the perils of what is hard to safeguard. Consider the likes of Shan Juan, Chao Fu, Guan Yin, and Hu Gong: all trod upon clouds and mist to soar aloft, relied on dragons and phoenixes to elevate their traces, discerned the sheathed blade within fragrant bait, and awakened to the overturned cart upon the road ahead. Shunning treacherous paths to avoid crossing, they evaded the hooks of Zhan He—truly adept at anticipating shadows beyond form and glimpsing solid ice in the first frost. They moved firewood before the blaze raged, furled sails and stilled oars before the gale struck, gazed at the nine oxen and sank deep, beheld the dense thicket and swiftly departed. They did not nest at the tip of the reed, nor lie supine beneath the crumbling cliff. Were these not men of vast capacity, profound insight, and keen perception, who surpassed their peers and walked alone, unbound by convention? Their desires aspired to merge with the Dao of creation, their hearts transcended the myriad things. Covetousness could not sting their purity, nor could turmoil disrupt their sincerity. If one lacks such innate integrity, how can it be attained? This is a path beyond the trodden track.

Yet those who know success often withdraw, for those who toil greatly are seldom rewarded. When the cunning hare is caught, the hunting hound is cast aside; when the high bird is felled, the fine bow is set to be discarded. Beholding the mirror of Peng and Han, one recalls the art of withdrawing the hairpin; witnessing the folly of the Yue lineage, one recognizes the value of gold and ivory. Like Lord Fan, who sailed away to escape the limelight, or Master Xue, who fled chaos to preserve his integrity; like the Two Shus, who resigned their seals at the height of abundance, or Tian Yu, who relinquished his sash as the candle waned—advancing avoids the calamity of overreaching, retreating spares the regret of trailing wet. Their pure wind is enough to scatter the dust of a thousand years, their virtuous resonance enough to dispel the delusions of ages to come. Compared to Chen and Dou, how distant they seem!

Yet some, though wise, fail in grand schemes; some, though strong, break under heavy burdens. Some, though uniquely right, are ensnared by the many; some, though wholly loyal, are impeached by those guarding all fronts. Some, advocating lofty plans, suffer the fate of Chao Cuo; some, exhausting heart and strength, meet the doom of Wu Qi. Thus, even those who tread cautiously and act with restraint may not escape. The Duke of Zhou was exiled, Confucius departed, Jia Yi was banished to the hinterlands, Sima Qian was branded innocent yet punished, Le Yi pacified Qi, Wu Zixu shattered Chu, Bai Qi expanded the realm with a hundred victories, Wenzi dominated Yue with nine strategies, Han Xin’s merits towered over the world, Qing Bu destroyed his family to aid the mandate—yet glory did not last a day before humiliation followed, nor did they shrink from its disaster. Were these truly wise men?

To serve as a minister is no easy task; in short, the crux lies in choosing one’s lord. I am not worthy to rely upon—such is the proof. To resign, yield to the worthy, preserve purity, and secure peace; to gain a fine name and ample reward—what greater fortune could there be? To cultivate this art is to grasp one in ten thousand chances. As fortune and misfortune are shaped by man, can one afford not to ponder this?

Those words that grate upon the ear are seldom met with joy; offerings of counsel bring honor, yet may invite ruin or disaster. When slander arises, how can one find the leisure to verify what to accept as true? When snares and nets fill the skies, even the fledgling mandarin duck hesitates to spread its wings; when pits and traps line every path, the unicorn and the sacred tiger retreat into hiding.

The passions cannot be indulged without limit, nor can desires be sated without end. The enlightened master their emotions through the Dao and dispel desires through strategy—how much more should those who scheme for others ensure loyalty, let alone fail to deliberate when plotting for themselves?

For the contented, there is ever sufficiency; the insatiable know no sufficiency. Constant sufficiency draws fortune, while insatiability invites calamity. To nourish life excessively is to hasten its end. The Song clan uprooted their seedlings, and the people of Ying exulted in Zhang Hua’s rise—yet their haste brought only withering and ruin. To know advance but forget retreat is to court destruction.

Few who race without restraint avoid stumbling; rare are those who tread waves without end who escape drowning. To wield blades without cease invites wounds; to strike without pause courts breakage. That fullness must yield to loss is the principle of nature—does the vessel of Zhou’s ancestral temple deceive us? Thus, when Yang You shot his arrows, passersby warned him to guard against the wind; when Dongye drove his chariot, Yanzi foresaw his downfall. Success and failure are not easily long endured.

The drinker need not always descend into chaos, yet most who do are drunk; wealth and nobility do not invariably lead to peril, yet peril often lurks within them. The wise foresee events in their earliest stirrings, fell trees at the first sign of a bud, refrain from boasting when blocks are stacked precariously, and discuss mending furs only after gathering all the fox pelts. The ancients feigned madness or folly—was this their delight? The times demanded it; they had no choice.

Some flee deep into the wilds only to meet waves, or hide in seclusion only to face fire—like Gong Sheng, who starved himself to death, or Li Ye, who swallowed poison in despair. Such fates arise from traces left behind, shadows that cannot be erased. Had their conduct been as cautious as treading ice, their bodies as still as dwelling in shade, their movements leaving no track to follow, and their quietude merging with non-action—would such misfortunes have befallen them? How much less for those who brandish the sun and moon to conceal their forms or beat war drums to seize weapons!

In an age of clarity, one may excel in aiding all under heaven; in an age of peril, one may barely preserve a single life. This lament is not unique to one scholar.

I have heard that no blaze is unquenched, no excess unchecked; brilliance bears the seeds of ash, and spring’s blossoms foretell autumn’s decay. The sun reaches its zenith and then declines; the moon waxes full and then wanes. The sequence of the four seasons ensures that all who achieve success must retreat. Observe the world: the loftiest structures, once they reach their limit, crumble. Turn to oneself: even fine meals and restrained drink, if immoderate, breed illness and harm one’s nature. How much more for those whose ambitions soar to the clouds without cease, whose power shakes rulers and whose honors mount without end?

The gnat guards against falling from a mountain only to soar freely, while the rhinoceros and tiger, if they plummet, shatter like scallions—this illustrates that great things cannot lose their proper place.

Moreover, when one in upright authority rebukes transgressions and follows the straight Way, when one strikes down those who violate discipline without considering enmity or grudges, resentment deepens and hatred accumulates. Yet if one abandons the law to indulge wrongdoing, if one heeds private pleas like an echo, if one spits out the hard and swallows the soft, bending the rule like a carpenter’s line—does not dwelling in such a position become wearisome?

Thus, those who preserve both body and reputation are exceedingly rare, while those who stumble and overturn their cauldrons are not few. Yet within, they recline in ornate chambers with graceful maidens, crimson curtains, and patterned canopies, their couches spread in lavish halls. Radiant beauties dazzle at their sides, their lithe forms and soft voices weaving songs of exquisite artistry—melodies like those of Song Yu and Cai Yong, the grace of *Yang’e*, their lips singing *Cai Ling* and *Yan Lu*, their feet tracing the steps of *Lü Shui* and the *Seven Disks*. Harmonious notes delight the ear, enchanting postures gladden the heart. Secret feasts follow one another, fine wine never withdrawn. Looking up, they ascend carved pavilions; gazing down, they reflect upon clear pools. They wander among fruit groves of crimson and emerald, sport in orchid gardens fragrant with blossoms. Patterned fish glide through the waves, red-feathered birds soar and wheel, arrows bring down swans from the clouds, chariot wheels drag bream and carp from afar. Rare treasures gather without seeking, luxuries arrive unbidden.

Abroad, their vermilion wheels gleam on the roads, lofty canopies press wheel to wheel, crimson banners billow like clouds, insignia and batons command awe, golden drums clamor, halberds and armor glitter. Proudly they ride in the rear carriage, their fine escorts filling the ranks. Their retinues exhaust the pleasures of sightseeing, their hunts and fishing reach the height of joy. Praise for their sagely brilliance fills their ears, while flattering words, spoken with one voice, dismiss the ancients—claiming Yi, Lü, Guan, and Yan are not their equals. How could they perceive the rise and fall as head and tail, joy and sorrow as morning and night? How could they willingly relinquish their exalted glory, beg to return their bones to the earth, turn their backs on vermilion gates, and return to the hills and gardens?

Now, if a sagely enlightened ruler sits above, great worthies assist in governance, the hundred offices are ordered only through them, and the myriad people are saved only through them—those who stand high without fearing peril, who are full without fearing excess—these are not the ones under discussion.

**Chapter Fifty: On Obscurity and Eminence**

Someone asked: *"Men of the same talent may yet meet with obscurity or eminence—what is the reason? Does this bind the swift and free, leaving them with regret?"*

The Master Embracing Simplicity replied: *"When abilities are no different, yet some are suppressed and others exalted, it is because they lack a true patron—thus, adversity and prosperity depend on the times. Success and failure are matters of fate. Those who discern the times—why lament their depths? Those who understand fate—why resent their lowly toil?*

*The *Zhanlu* and *Chungou* swords are of the finest steel, yet if not wielded, they cannot even sever morning mushrooms. The *Yaohua* and *Lilü* are treasures beyond price, yet if cast into the mire, tiles and pebbles pile upon them. Thus, things may be precious yet not necessarily prized, may be useful yet not necessarily employed.*

*The vulgar, blind to distinctions, cannot tell red from purple, nor beans from wheat. They deem the eminent worthy merely because they have risen, unaware that what they seek is but fleeting success. They scorn the obscure as inferior, yet do not examine those who uphold the Dao and remain in obscurity.*

*Moreover, the celestial bodies, if not fixed in the heavens, cannot radiate their great light to illumine all without exception. Mount Song and Mount Tai, if not rooted in the earth, cannot tower to the clouds. The hare’s swiftness depends on level ground to gallop, the dragon’s boat rides the rushing currents to display its speed. Fire’s brilliance did not blaze until Suiren, the sharpness of Chu steel was not honed until Ou Ye. Luxuriant blossoms await spring to display their splendor, soaring swans rely on the gale to glide lightly.*

*If the Four Mountains do not commend the worthy, then even the most capable remain unrecognized. If Ya did not recommend Guan Zhong, then Yi Wu would not have been employed. Rangju owed his rise to Pingzhong, Han Xin’s soaring began with Xiao He. Junsheng’s eloquence came from Shengzhi’s counsel, Qu Ni’s advancement stemmed from Wuzhi’s recommendation. Kongming emerged from Longzhong, Gongjin’s fame arose from Gongwo’s support. Thus, their illustrious names were recorded in the imperial annals, their meritorious deeds inscribed in their era.*

They invariably favored those who aligned with themselves, making such attachment the foremost criterion for selection. Those with many factions were invariably chosen, yet those who aligned with them were not necessarily vessels fit for advancement. Those who echoed their own views could not be cast aside, yet those with many factions were not necessarily talents surpassing the common herd. Trusting the clamor of the crowd, they deemed such men worthy; or, believing these to be mediocre and base, they could not relinquish their attachment to the familiar and the near. Or, recognizing those others as exceptional and outstanding, they could not maintain impartiality in utmost fairness. Thus, they cast aside the scales of assessment and took frequency of association as the measure of weight; they abandoned standards of measure and took the density of connections as the gauge of quantity. At such times, those so-called refined men of lofty bearing who wielded the state’s power of promotion and demotion—whose decisions of praise and censure were dictated by mere words—were rare indeed to escape this entanglement. How much more so when, in their hearts, they suddenly harbored hatred, stood alone in resentment, envied those not of their faction, or despised the independent and superior, or scorned the poor and unconnected?

Alas! The scholars of distant custom and the men of unparalleled distinction—those who, generation after generation, failed to meet with recognition—cannot be numbered. Some were suppressed and languished in marshes and wilds; others stood in court only to be cast out. Some cultivated virtue yet their Way did not prevail; some stored their talents yet the times did not guard them. Some waited for the Yellow River to run clear until their teeth had fallen out; some exhausted their loyalty and diligence yet were not known or employed. Their far-reaching influence did not extend to their age; their beneficent deeds did not reach the people. Treasures fit for the banquet mat lay mired in mud; talents for aiding the world ended without application. Like the man who played the zither yet did not meet King Wu Ding, or the one who held the fishing pole yet did not encounter King Wen—from ancient times to the present, how many have there been? Yet to lament this alone is indeed narrow-minded.

To gaze upon the distant path and be ashamed to follow it, to know the great Dao is obstructed yet not change course, to equate success and failure on a single road, to consign honor and disgrace to nature—how could one harbor melancholy in the face of scarce understanding, or sigh forever at the passing of rivers? To suspect resentment in this is to fail to comprehend the mind of the perfected person.

The ignorance of short-lived creatures regarding the long-lived, the frog in the well’s incomprehension of the vast sea—these have always been so.

**Chapter Fifty-One**
The *Baopuzi* states: There was a man called Master Tranquil and Profound. Though his years were but those of one who studies the will, he had already exhaustively perused the Six Classics and broadly synthesized the *He* and *Luo* texts. By day, he contended with the last rays of Xi He; by night, he illuminated the lingering glow of Wang Shu. No Dao was too distant for him to fathom; no word was too obscure for him to plumb. He took Confucianism and Daoism as his city walls, his spiritual acuity as his weapons. Thus, those who discoursed could not but trail dust and proffer jade in his presence; scholars, upon setting eyes on him, laid down their brushes. Soon, they awoke to the wisdom of silence and realized the blamelessness of guarding the One. When his intent was fulfilled, he deemed the fish-trap and rabbit-snare discardable; when the Dao diverged, he perceived that lofty singing finds few harmonies.

Thereupon, he embraced Laozi’s caution against frequent defeat and pondered the admonition of the golden man’s triple-sealed lips. He sheathed his blade’s edge as if encasing it, polished his brush on the vermilion tube, held gold and jade within, and restrained his florid eloquence. From dawn to dusk, he might utter not a single word. His disciples approached and said: “Master, you remain silent—how can your disciples expound? You differ not from the common man.”

I privately thought: If the great bell does not sound, it is no different from a heap of bronze; if the floating chime ceases its tone, it is indistinguishable from a pile of stones.

Master Tranquil and Profound replied: “I seek only to gather a distant name across ten thousand generations and find a true friend in the ages to come. How could I vie for recognition in this day or set my standard in this moment? A vessel for brewing fine wine, though excellent, does not itself become drunk. One who speaks humbly yet loftily, though correct, is not believed. To curl the tongue and exhaust the voice—what remedy is there for fleeing and evasion? The ancients laughed at fifty-nine when they reached sixty; only then did they realize the depth of their past delusion.

For jade is hard, and gold is strong.”

The cold of ice and the heat of fire—do they require self-proclamation to be known? Moreover, the eight tones and nine suites cannot avoid flaws of length or brevity; even Yang You’s hundred shots cannot prevent an occasional miss. Those who cross rivers without boats often drown in water; those fond of heated debate frequently slip in speech. Bo Ya was cautious with his strings, thus avoiding the burden of tangled fingers; the scholar guards his words, thus escaping the shame of careless slips. The shallow and vulgar act otherwise: they dispute the urgency of emptiness and nothingness, squander words on trivial matters, and expound at length on the useless doctrines of "hard and white." They litigate against the masters, condemn the sages, and fault the upright, calling such misguidance "profound." They cast aside the true classics to vie in heterodox studies, or match wits with the ignorant in contests of lip and tongue, spouting lofty discourse to those who cannot comprehend. The Master of Embracing Simplicity, surnamed Ge, named Hong, styled Zhichuan, was a native of Jurong in Danyang. His ancestors descended from the Ge Tian clan, who once ruled all under heaven in ancient times. Later, they were demoted to the ranks of feudal lords and took Ge as their surname. Hong’s great-grandfather served as Inspector of Jingzhou. When Wang Mang usurped the throne, he scorned to serve a traitorous regime, resigned his post, and returned home. Together with Zhai Yi, Governor of Dongjun, he raised troops to punish Wang Mang but was defeated. Pardoned and spared from disaster, he feigned illness and withdrew from the world. Fearing that the Ge clan’s strength might eventually provoke unrest, Wang Mang relocated them to Langye. Hong’s grandfather, Pu, raised an army to aid Emperor Guangwu, rendering great service. After Guangwu ascended the throne, Pu was appointed General of Chariots and Cavalry, later promoted to General of Agile Cavalry, and enfeoffed as Marquis of Xiapei and Tongxian, with a fief of five thousand households. At the founding of the dynasty, Pu’s younger brother, Wen, followed the marquis on campaigns and achieved repeated victories. The marquis repeatedly memorialized the throne to commend Wen’s merits, but the court, citing Wen’s private service under his elder cousin without official military rank, refused to acknowledge his contributions. The marquis declared, “My brother and I together faced arrows and stones, our bodies covered in wounds, my right eye lost—yet he has received no reward, while I am laden with gold and purple. How can my heart be at ease?” He then petitioned to transfer his own enfeoffment to his brother. The emperor, wishing to honor the marquis’s noble integrity, granted the request. Wen, though reluctant, accepted the title and immediately ceded his residence to become the encampment of the General of Agile Cavalry, establishing his estate in Bowang Ward. To this day, its foundations and stone pillars remain. He also divided his stipends to provide for his officers and soldiers, treating them as generously as the two former marquises. The General of Agile Cavalry repeatedly urged him to desist, but Wen refused, saying, “This only burdens the people further. How can I accept?” Feigning other business, he crossed the Yangtze southward and settled in Jurong, where his descendants tilled the land and found solace in books. Though Wen repeatedly sent envoys to welcome the General of Agile Cavalry, the latter never returned. Instead, he stationed guards to maintain the estate in Bowang, hoping for the general’s eventual return—yet for generations, no one resided there.

Hong’s grandfather was a scholar of unparalleled breadth, mastering all fields of learning with profound precision. His literary and artistic attainments stood peerless in his time, and he possessed the talent to govern a state. Serving the Kingdom of Wu, he held successive posts as Magistrate of Haiyan, Lin’an, and Shanyin, then entered the capital as Gentleman of the Ministry of Personnel, Palace Aide to the Censor-in-Chief, Governor of Luling, Minister of Personnel, Junior Preceptor to the Crown Prince, President of the Imperial Secretariat, Grand Master of Ceremonies, Palace Attendant, and Intendant of the Palace Guards. He was also appointed General of Assisting Wu and enfeoffed as Marquis of Wushou. Hong’s father was renowned for his filial piety and fraternal devotion, a model for scholars. His conduct and learning were exhaustively recorded in official histories. He served Wu as Gentleman of the Five Offices, Prefect of Jiancheng and Nanchang, Gentleman of the Imperial Secretariat, and Minister of Justice, then as General of the Guards. He was appointed Governor of Kuaiji but had not yet assumed office when the Jin army advanced downstream, and the western borders collapsed. Recognizing his literary and martial talents, the court and populace unanimously recommended him. He was thus transferred to serve as Commander-in-Chief of Five Commanderies, charged with defending the frontier, granted five thousand personal troops, and placed in command of all expeditionary forces. Yet when heaven decrees ruin, human effort cannot prevail. As the former lord submitted to the Nine Provinces’ shared fate, Hong’s father, retaining his former rank, was summoned to serve as Gentleman of the Palace, gradually rising to the position of Grand Master of Splendid Happiness. He later served as Magistrate of Feixiang, a county of twenty thousand households, where his governance was deemed the finest in the province. His moral transformation was exceptional, his benevolence pervasive, his punishments just, and his domain peaceful, earning him widespread praise. Roads were free of bandits, and no one tilled public fields or crossed boundaries to trade. Even the smallest gifts were refused at his gate, while paper and brushes were supplied from his private funds. Through punishments, order was maintained; without words, transformation was achieved. He resigned due to illness, but an imperial edict summoned him to serve as Prefect of Wu, where he upheld strict integrity, correcting errors, promoting the worthy, and exposing the corrupt. The state and military were governed with solemn harmony. Later, he was appointed Governor of Shaoling and died in office.

Hong was his father’s third son. Born late in his parents’ lives, he was doted upon and not strictly disciplined in books and history. At the age of thirteen, he lost his kind father, prematurely deprived of paternal instruction. Struggling with hunger and cold, he personally tilled the fields, laboring beneath the stars and treading upon frost, diligently following the plow. Repeatedly ravaged by war and fire, his family’s books were utterly destroyed. During rare moments of respite from farming, with nothing to read, he carried his satchel and walked to borrow books, only to find that few households possessed complete collections. Thus, he redoubled his efforts, cutting and selling firewood to purchase paper and brushes, writing books by the light of kindling in his thatched hut. For this reason, he could not early immerse himself in the arts and literature. Often lacking paper, he wrote on the same sheets repeatedly, rendering his texts barely legible. At sixteen, he began studying the *Classic of Filial Piety*, the *Analects*, the *Book of Songs*, and the *Book of Changes*. Yet poverty prevented him from seeking distant teachers and friends, leaving him isolated and poorly informed, his thoughts shallow and his understanding limited. Many great principles remained beyond his grasp. Eager to read widely, he devoured all manner of books, memorizing whatever he encountered. Yet his nature was dull and forgetful, his will not steadfast, and his retention weak. Though he sometimes drew upon his readings in his writings, he never achieved the depth of a true Confucian scholar and was unfit to serve as a teacher. The *River Chart* and *Luo Writing*, along with apocryphal texts, he merely glanced at without deep engagement. He disliked astrological manuals, calculations, the Nine Palaces, three-player chess, *Taiyi* divination, and flying talismans, finding no affinity for such arts. Later, he dabbled in wind angles, qi observation, the Three Origins, *Dunjia*, *Liuren*, and *Taiyi* methods, gaining only a rough understanding without deep study. He concluded that such practices were tools for others’ use, mere distractions from self-cultivation. Believing that reducing desires was more beneficial, he abandoned them. According to the *Separate Record of Arts and Letters*, there were 13,299 volumes of books, and since the Wei dynasty, the corpus had doubled. Thus, he realized how much he had yet to see. Books from the south of the Yangtze were incomplete, and he once journeyed to the capital in search of rare and extraordinary texts, only to be thwarted by great chaos, forcing him to turn back midway. Each time, he sighed with regret. Now nearing forty, his youthful aspirations have waned. He thinks only of diminishing desires further, practicing non-action, and perhaps retiring to the marshes to preserve his life. His pursuit of broad learning has thus daily declined.

chunks.original_text: 洪之为人朴而呆野性钝口讷形貌丑陋而终不办自矜饰也 冠履垢弊衣或蓝缕而或不耻焉 俗之服用俄而屡改或忽广领而大带或身促而修防或长裾曳地或短不蔽脚洪期于守常不随世变言则率实杜绝嘲戏不得其人终日默然故人咸称之为抱朴之士是以洪着书因以自号焉 洪禀性尪羸兼之多疾贫无车马不堪徒行行亦性所不好又患弊俗舍本逐末交游过差故遂抚笔闲居守静荜门而无趋从之所至于权豪之徒虽在密迹而莫或相识焉 衣不辟寒室不免漏食不充虚名不出户不能忧也 贫无僮仆篱落顿决荆棘丛于庭宇蓬莠塞乎 阶溜披榛出门排草入室论者以为意远忽近而不怒其乏役也 不晓谒以故初不修见官常至于吊大丧省困疾乃心欲自勉强令无不至而居疾少捷恒复不周每见讥责于论者洪引咎而不恤也 意苟无余而病使心违顾不媿己而已亦何理于人之不见亮乎 惟明鉴之士乃恕其信抱朴非以养高也 世人多慕豫亲之好推暗至之密洪以为知人甚未易上圣之所难浮杂之交口合神疵无益有损虽不能如朱公叔一旦绝之且必须清澄详悉乃处意焉 又为此见憎者甚众而不改也 驰逐苟达侧立势门者又共疾洪之异于己而见疵毁谓洪为傲物轻俗而洪之为人信心而行毁誉皆置于不闻至患近人或恃其所长而轻人所短洪忝为儒者之末每与人言常度其所知而论之不强引之以造彼所不闻也 及与学士有所辩识每举纲领若值惜短难解心家但粗说意之与向使足以发悟而已不致苦理使彼率不得自还也 彼静心者详而思之则多自觉而得之者焉 度不与言者虽或有问常辞以不知以免辞费之过也 洪性深不好干烦官长自少及长曾救知己之抑者数人不得有言于在位者然其人皆不知洪之恤也 不忍见其陷于非理密自营之耳 其余虽亲至者在事秉势与洪无识者终不以片言半字少累之也 至于粮用穷匮急合汤药则唤求朋或见济亦不让也 受人之施必皆乆乆渐有以报之不令觉也 非则不妄受其馈致焉 洪所食有旬日之储则分以济人之乏若殊自不足亦不割己也 不为皎皎之细行不治察察之小廉村里凡人之谓良善者用时或赍酒殽候洪虽不俦匹亦不拒也 后有以答之亦不登时也 洪尝谓史云不食于昆弟华生治洁于昵客盖邀名之伪行非廊庙之远量也 洪尤疾无义之人不勤农桑之本业而慕非义之奸利持乡论者则卖选举以取谢有威势者则解符疏以索财或有罪人之赂或枉有理之家或为逋逃之薮而飨亡命之人或挟使民丁以妨公役或强收钱物以求贵价或占锢市肆夺百姓之利或割人田地劫孤弱之业惚恫官府之间以窥掊克之益内以夸妻妾外以钓名位其如此者不与交焉 由是俗人憎洪疾己自然疏绝故巷无车马之迹堂无异志之宾庭可设雀罗而几筵积尘焉 洪自有识逮以将老口不及人之非不说人之私乃自然也 虽仆竖有所短所羞之事不以戏之也 未尝论评人物之优劣不喜诃谴人交之好恶或为尊长所逼问辞不获己其论人也 则独举彼体中之胜事而已其论文也 则撮其所得之佳者而不指摘其病累故无毁誉之怨贵人时或问官吏民甲乙何如其清高闲能者洪指说其快事其贪暴暗塞者对以偶不识悉洪由此颇见讥责以顾防太多不能明辨臧否使皂白区分而洪终不敢改也 每见世人有好论人物者比方伦匹未必当允而褒贬与夺或失准格见誉者自谓已分未必信德也 见侵者则恨之入骨剧于血雠洪益以为戒遂不复言及士人矣

Ge Hong was a man of simple and rustic bearing, dull by nature, slow of speech, and plain in appearance, yet he never sought to adorn or refine himself. His hats and shoes were filthy and worn, his robes often tattered, and he felt no shame in this. As worldly fashions swiftly changed—now broad collars and wide sashes, now tight sleeves and long hems, now trailing skirts, now garments too short to cover the feet—he remained steadfast in his ways, refusing to follow the shifts of the age. His words were always plain and truthful, free of jest or mockery. When no suitable companion was at hand, he would pass the entire day in silence. Thus, all who knew him called him a man who "embraced simplicity," and so he took this as the title for his writings.

By nature, Ge Hong was frail and sickly, and poverty left him without carriage or horse. He could not bear to walk, nor did he enjoy it, and he despised the degenerate customs of his time—how men abandoned fundamentals to chase trivialities, how they overindulged in socializing. Thus, he took up his brush in seclusion, dwelling in stillness behind a wattle gate, with no place to rush to or follow after. Even those in power, though near at hand, scarcely knew him. His clothes could not ward off the cold, his roof could not keep out the rain, and his food could not fill his stomach. Yet fame never crossed his threshold, and he could not bring himself to care. Poor, with no servants, his fences collapsed, brambles choked his courtyard, and weeds overran his steps. When he ventured out, he pushed through thickets; when he returned, he brushed past overgrowth. Observers thought him lofty of mind, neglectful of the mundane, and never resentful of his hardships.

Unskilled in formal visits, he never paid respects to officials. Yet when it came to mourning the dead or tending to the sick, he would force himself to go, sparing no effort. But his frailty and frequent illnesses often left him unable to fulfill these duties, and critics would reproach him. Ge Hong accepted the blame without concern. He thought: if his intentions were pure and illness alone prevented him, why should he feel shame? What reason had others not to understand? Only those of clear discernment would forgive him, recognizing that his embrace of simplicity was not a ploy to cultivate loftiness.

Most men cherished the warmth of close bonds and prized the intimacy of those who came to them in ignorance. Ge Hong, however, believed that truly knowing another was no easy task—even the sages found it difficult. Superficial friendships, where words aligned but minds clashed, brought no benefit, only harm. Though he could not sever ties as abruptly as Zhuangzi’s friend did, he insisted on clarity and thorough understanding before committing to a relationship. For this, he was deeply resented, yet he never changed.

Those who chased success and stood obsequiously at the gates of the powerful despised Ge Hong for his difference, slandering him as arrogant and dismissive of custom. But Ge Hong was a man of unwavering conviction; praise and blame alike fell on deaf ears. He loathed those who, relying on their own strengths, belittled the weaknesses of others. As one of the least among Confucians, when he spoke with others, he always gauged their understanding and discussed only what they could grasp, never forcing them toward what they could not comprehend.

When debating with scholars, he would lay out the essentials. If he encountered someone of limited ability, he would offer only a rough sketch of his ideas, just enough to spark insight, without pressing the finer points to the point of confusion. Those who listened with a calm mind and pondered deeply often found their own realizations. When he judged someone unfit for discussion, even if questioned, he would plead ignorance to avoid wasting words.

By nature, Ge Hong deeply disliked imposing on officials or superiors. From youth to old age, he had secretly aided several friends in distress, yet none knew it was he who had helped them. He could not bear to see others wronged and would quietly intervene on their behalf. But for all others—even close relatives—if they held power or influence and were strangers to him, he would not trouble them with so much as a word or half a character.

When his supplies ran low and he urgently needed medicine, he would ask friends for help, and if they provided, he accepted without refusal. Any assistance he received, he repaid gradually over time, ensuring the giver never noticed. If the aid did not come from a friend, he would not accept it. When his own provisions lasted ten days, he would share them to relieve others’ needs. But if his own stores were insufficient, he would not deprive himself.

He did not strive for petty displays of virtue or meticulous scruples. Among villagers, those deemed "good and kind" would sometimes bring wine and dishes to visit him. Though he did not consider them his equals, he did not refuse them. If he later repaid the gesture, he did not do so immediately.

Ge Hong once remarked on the historian’s account of a man who refused to eat with his brothers but kept his table spotless for guests: such was the false conduct of those seeking fame, not the magnanimity of a statesman. He particularly despised those without principle—men who neglected the fundamentals of farming and weaving to pursue illicit gains. Some sold official appointments for bribes; others exploited their influence to extort wealth. Some took bribes from criminals, others wronged the innocent. Some harbored fugitives and sheltered outlaws; others conscripted laborers to obstruct public works. Some hoarded goods to inflate prices; others monopolized markets to seize profits from the people. Some seized fields and robbed the weak of their livelihoods. They cowered before officials, seeking opportunities to exploit, then flaunted their gains before their wives and concubines or used them to buy fame and rank. With such men, Ge Hong refused all association.

Thus, the worldly despised him, and naturally, they kept their distance. No carriage tracks marred his lane, no guests of differing minds crossed his hall. His courtyard could have been set with bird nets, and his tables gathered dust. From the time he first gained understanding until his later years, his lips never uttered another’s faults, nor did he delight in others’ secrets—this came naturally to him. Even his servants, if they had shortcomings or shameful acts, he never mocked. He never judged or ranked people’s strengths and weaknesses, nor did he enjoy scolding others. If pressed by superiors to speak of someone’s likes or dislikes, he would only mention their finest qualities. When discussing writing, he would highlight its best aspects, never pointing out its flaws. Thus, he incurred no resentment for praise or blame.

When powerful men occasionally asked him about officials or commoners—who was pure, who was capable—he would extol the virtues of the upright and talented. For the greedy, violent, or ignorant, he would claim to know nothing of them. For this, he was often criticized, accused of being overly cautious, unable to clearly distinguish right from wrong. Yet Ge Hong never altered his ways.

He often saw how people, when discussing others, would compare and rank them, their praise and criticism often misplaced. Those who were praised would take it as their due, though their virtue might not be genuine. Those who were slighted would hate their detractors to the bone, as if they were blood enemies. Ge Hong took this as a warning and thereafter never spoke of others.

When engaging with scholars, he would grasp the main points. If he encountered someone of limited understanding, he would offer only a rough outline of his ideas, just enough to inspire insight, without pressing the finer points to the point of confusion. Those who listened with a calm mind and pondered deeply often found their own realizations. If he judged someone unfit for discussion, even if questioned, he would plead ignorance to avoid wasting words. His nature deeply disliked imposing on officials or superiors. But for others—even close relatives—if they held power and were strangers to him, he would not trouble them with so much as a word.

If the aid did not come from a friend, he would not accept it. When his provisions lasted ten days, he would share them to relieve others’ needs, but if his own stores were insufficient, he would not deprive himself. He did not strive for petty displays of virtue or meticulous scruples. Among villagers, those deemed "good and kind" would sometimes bring wine and dishes to visit him. Though he did not consider them his equals, he did not refuse them. If he later repaid the gesture, he did not do so immediately.

Books from the south of the Yangtze were incomplete, and he once journeyed to the capital in search of rare and extraordinary texts, only to be thwarted by great chaos, forcing him to turn back midway. Each time, he sighed with regret. Now nearing forty, his youthful aspirations have waned. He thinks only of diminishing desires further, practicing non-action, and perhaps retiring to the marshes to preserve his life. His pursuit of broad learning has thus daily declined.

chunks.original_text: 虽门宗子弟其称两皆以付族不为轻乎 其价数也 或以讥洪洪答曰我身在我者也 法当易知设令有人问我使自比古人及同时令我自求辈则我实不能自知可与谁为匹也 况非我安可为取评定之汉末俗弊朋党分部许子将之徒以口舌取戒争讼论议门宗成雠故汝南人士无复定价而有月旦之评魏武帝深亦疾之欲取其首尔乃奔波亡走殆至屠灭前鉴不远可以得师矣 且人之未易知也 虽父兄不必尽子弟也 同于我者遽是乎 异于我者遽非乎 或有始无卒唐尧公旦仲尼季札皆有不全得之恨无以近人信其喽喽管见荧烛之明而轻人评物是皆迈彼上圣大贤乎 昔大安中石氷作乱六州之地村镇业靡违正党逆义军大都督邀洪为将兵都尉累见敦迫暨桑梓恐虏祸深忧大古人有急疾之义又畏军法不敢任志遂募合数百人与诸军旅进曾攻贼之别将破之日钱帛山积珍玩蔽地诸军莫不放兵收拾财物继毂连担洪独约令所领不得妄离行阵士有摭得众者洪即斩之以徇于是无敢委权而果有伏贼数百出伤诸军诸军悉发无部队皆人马负重无复战心遂致惊乱死伤狼藉殆欲不振独洪军整齐毂帐无所损失以救诸军之大崩洪有力焉 后别战斩贼小帅多获甲首而献捷幕府于是大都督加洪伏波将军例给布百疋诸将多封闭之或送还家而洪分赐将士及施知故之贫者余之十匹又径以市肉酤酒以飨将吏于时窃擅一日之美谈焉 事平洪投戈释甲径诣洛阳欲广寻异书了不论战功窃慕鲁连不受聊城之金包胥不纳存楚之赏成功不处之义焉 正遇上国大乱北道不通而陈敏又反于江东归涂隔塞防有故人谯国居道见用为广州刺史乃表请洪为参军虽非所乐然利可避地于南故黾勉就焉 见遣先行催兵而居道于后遇害遂停广州频为节将见邀用皆不就永惟富贵可以渐得而不可顿合其间屑屑亦足以劳人且荣位势利譬如寄客既非常物又其去不可得留也 隆隆者绝赫赫者灭有若春华须防凋落得之不喜失之安悲悔吝百端忧惧竞战不可胜言不足为也 且自度性笃懒而才至短以笃懒而御短才虽翕肩屈膝趋走风尘犹必不办大致名位而免患累况不能乎 未若修松乔之道在我而已不由于人焉 将登名山服食养性非有废也 事不兼济自不绝弃世务则曷缘修习静哉 且知之诚难以不得借问而与人议也 是以车马之迹不经贵世之域片字之书不交在位之家又士林之中虽不可出而见造之宾意不能拒妨人所作不得专一乃叹曰山林之中无道也 而古之修道者必入山林诚欲以违远讙哗使心不乱也 今将遂本志委桑梓适嵩岳以寻方平梁公之轨先所作子书内外篇幸已用功夫聊复撰次以示来者云尔洪年十五六时所作诗赋杂文当时自谓可行至于弱冠更详省之殊多不称意天才未必为増也 直所览差广而觉妍媸之别于是大有所制弃十不存一今除所作子书但杂尚余百卷犹未尽损益之理而多惨愤不遑复料护之他人文成手便快意余才钝思迟实不能示作文章每一更字辄自转胜但患懒又所作多不能数省之耳 洪年二十余乃计作细碎小文妨弃功日未若立一家之言乃草创子书防遇兵乱流离播越有所亡失连在道路不复投笔十余年至建武中乃定凡着内篇二十卷外篇五十卷碑颂诗赋百卷军书檄移章表笺记三十卷又撰俗所不列者为神仙传十卷又撰高尚不仕者为隐逸传十卷又抄五经七史百家之言兵事方伎短杂奇要三百一十卷别有目录其内篇言神仙方药怪变化养生延年禳邪却祸之事属道家其外篇言人间得失世事臧否属儒家洪见魏文帝典目自叙未及弹棋击剑之事有意于略说所知而实不数少所便能不可虚自称扬今将具言所不闲焉

Though his clan’s disciples and younger kin might deem such a stance too lenient, he would assign them both praise and blame without distinction. Some mocked him for this, to which he replied: “My person belongs to me. The principle should be easy to grasp. Suppose someone asked me to compare myself to the ancients or to my contemporaries, forcing me to rank myself—truly, I could not know with whom I might be matched. How much less should I presume to judge those who are not myself?

In the late Han, the corruption of custom gave rise to factions and cliques. Men like Xu Shao and his ilk wielded their tongues to issue warnings and engage in disputes, turning debates into feuds. Thus, the scholars of Runan had no fixed reputations, only the monthly evaluations of character. Even Emperor Wu of Wei deeply despised this and sought to behead them, driving them to flee in panic, nearly to the point of annihilation. The lesson lies close at hand—one may well take it as a teacher.

Moreover, people are not easily known. Even fathers and elder brothers may not fully understand their sons and younger brothers. Is what aligns with me necessarily right? Is what differs from me necessarily wrong? Some begin well but end poorly. Yao, the Duke of Zhou, Confucius, and Jizha all lamented their own incompleteness. How can those of us with narrow, flickering candlelight vision presume to judge others and assess their worth? Do we surpass those sagely and virtuous ancients?

During the Da’an era, Shi Bing rebelled, ravaging six provinces. Villages and towns were laid waste, and the righteous cause was overturned. The Grand Marshal of the Righteous Army summoned Hong to serve as a general and captain. Repeatedly pressed, and fearing deep calamity would befall his homeland, he recalled the ancient principle of aiding those in dire peril. Yet he also dreaded military discipline and dared not act on his own will. Thus, he recruited several hundred men and joined the army in its advance. Once, they attacked a separate rebel force and routed them. On that day, coins and silks piled like mountains, and treasures covered the ground. The other armies all released their soldiers to gather spoils, their carts and packs stretching end to end. Hong alone ordered his troops not to stray from formation. If any soldier was found looting, Hong immediately executed him as an example. Thus, none dared abandon their posts. Later, when hundreds of ambushers emerged to strike the other armies, those forces had scattered, their men and horses burdened with plunder, their fighting spirit gone. They fell into chaos, suffering heavy casualties, nearly beyond recovery. Only Hong’s troops remained orderly, their carts and tents undamaged, saving the other armies from total collapse. Hong’s merit was great in this.

In a later battle, he slew a minor rebel chieftain and captured many suits of armor and heads, presenting them as trophies to headquarters. The Grand Marshal then bestowed upon Hong the title of General Fubo, along with a gift of a hundred bolts of cloth, following standard practice. Many officers sealed their rewards or sent them home, but Hong distributed his among his officers and soldiers, as well as to impoverished acquaintances. Of the hundred bolts, he kept only ten for himself, then immediately used them to buy meat and wine to feast his officers and men. For a time, this became the talk of the day.

When the conflict ended, Hong cast aside his weapons and armor and headed straight for Luoyang, seeking to expand his collection of rare books. He made no mention of his military achievements, secretly admiring the principle of Lu Lian, who refused gold from Liaocheng, and Wu Zixu, who declined rewards for preserving Chu—embracing the virtue of not dwelling on success.

Just then, the capital fell into great turmoil, and the northern roads were blocked. Chen Min rebelled in Jiangdong, cutting off the return route. An old friend, Dong Ju, who had been appointed Governor of Guangzhou, submitted a memorial requesting Hong as his adjutant. Though the post was not to his liking, the south offered a refuge, so he reluctantly accepted. Sent ahead to muster troops, he waited for Dong Ju to follow, but Dong was killed en route. Hong thus remained in Guangzhou, frequently invited by regional commanders to serve, but he declined every offer.

He reflected: wealth and honor may be gradually attained but cannot be seized all at once. The pursuit of such things is wearisome and enough to exhaust a person. Moreover, glory and power are like lodgers—neither permanent nor something one can cling to. What rises high will inevitably fall; what blazes bright will fade. Like spring blossoms, they must wither. To rejoice in gaining them or grieve in losing them is to invite endless regret, sorrow, and fear—struggles too numerous to name. They are not worth the trouble.

Assessing his own nature, he found it deeply indolent, his talents severely limited. Even if he were to bow and scrape, rushing about in the dust, he would surely fail to achieve great fame or avoid entanglements—how much more so given his inability? Better to cultivate the Way of Master Red Pine and Wang Qiao, which lies within oneself and does not depend on others.

He aspired to ascend famous mountains, practice dietary arts, and nurture his nature—not out of neglect for worldly affairs, but because one cannot serve both at once. If he did not abandon worldly duties, how could he cultivate tranquility and the profound?

Moreover, true understanding is difficult and cannot be borrowed through inquiry or discussion. Thus, his carriage and horses never entered the domains of the powerful, and not a single word of his writing was exchanged with those in office. Though he could not entirely withdraw from the scholar’s circle, he refused to receive visitors. When others’ works infringed upon his own, he could not maintain his focus. He sighed: “There is no Dao in the mountains and forests.” Yet the ancients who cultivated the Dao invariably entered the mountains and forests, truly seeking to distance themselves from clamor and prevent their minds from being disturbed.

Now, he would fulfill his original aspiration: leaving his homeland, he would journey to Mount Song to seek the path of Fangping and Liang Gong. His earlier work, the *Master’s Book*, in both inner and outer chapters, had fortunately already been completed. He would now compile and arrange it to show to future generations.

At fifteen or sixteen, he had written poems, rhapsodies, and miscellaneous essays, which he then believed were passable. By the time he reached twenty, he reviewed them again and found much unsatisfactory. His talent had not necessarily improved—only his reading had broadened, and he now discerned the difference between the refined and the coarse. Thus, he discarded most of his earlier work, keeping less than one-tenth. Excluding the *Master’s Book*, he still had over a hundred scrolls of miscellaneous writings, though many remained unrevised, filled with sorrow and indignation, and he lacked the leisure to refine them further.

Others wrote swiftly, finding satisfaction in their work as soon as it was done. But his own talent was dull, his thoughts slow, and he could not produce polished prose on demand. Each time he revised a character, the text improved, but his laziness and the volume of his work prevented frequent review.

In his twenties, he had calculated that writing minor, trivial pieces wasted time better spent establishing a coherent philosophy. Thus, he began drafting the *Master’s Book*. However, war and upheaval scattered him, and some works were lost. For over a decade on the road, he did not take up his brush. Only in the Jianwu era did he finally settle, completing twenty inner chapters and fifty outer chapters, along with a hundred scrolls of stele inscriptions, eulogies, poems, and rhapsodies. He also wrote thirty scrolls of military documents, proclamations, letters, and memorials. Additionally, he compiled works not included in common catalogs: the *Biographies of Divine Immortals* in ten scrolls, the *Biographies of Recluses* in ten scrolls, and an anthology of essential passages from the Five Classics, the Seven Histories, the Hundred Schools, military affairs, techniques, and miscellaneous wonders, totaling three hundred and ten scrolls, each with its own catalog.

The inner chapters discuss matters of Daoist concern: divine immortals, elixirs, strange transformations, life-nourishing practices, longevity techniques, and methods to ward off misfortune. The outer chapters address Confucian themes: human successes and failures, and the right and wrong of worldly affairs.

Hong noted that Emperor Wen of Wei’s *Canon of Classics* omitted mention of games like tanqi and swordplay. He intended to briefly record what he knew, but in truth, his skills were few and minor, and he could not boast falsely. Now, he would fully describe what he had not yet mastered.

chunks.translated_text:
Ge Hong’s nature was dull and his talents mediocre. From the time his hair was first tied up in childhood, he lagged behind other boys in tossing tiles or wrestling. He never fought cocks, raced dogs or horses, and when he saw others gambling, he paid no heed. Even when dragged along to watch, he remained utterly disengaged, as if dozing in broad daylight. To this day, he does not know how many lines are on a chessboard or the names of the dice in *chupu*. He considers such pastimes trivial arts that scatter the mind and waste time. For officials, they harm governance; for scholars, they disrupt recitation; for commoners, they cause neglect of farming; for merchants, they lead to loss of goods. Before the outcome is decided, players grow heated in dispute, their faces flushed with anger, calling this "amusement" when in truth it is torment. It erodes integrity, sparks contention, invites heavy wagers, and breeds hidden grudges. In the past, Duke Min of Song and the Crown Prince of Wu met with fatal disasters, while the rebellion of the Seven States nearly toppled the imperial court—lessons bright as mirrors for a hundred generations. Whenever he observed players, he saw them flushed with shame and rage, striking out with hands and feet, hurling insults, severing friendships, and breaking ties—all too common. Resentment does not depend on scale; whether great or small, it often brings regret. Such pursuits are not worth the trouble.

Confucius warned against dozing in the daytime, but compared to Ge Hong, even that seems preferable. Daytime dozing is merely unproductive, whereas it does not risk resentment or litigation. The sage still wore out bamboo strips three times in his devotion to the classics—how could an ordinary man of modest talent manage both? All such games are inferior to even a foot of books. Thus, he naturally disliked them and never engaged, though such pastimes are dear to the common crowd.

In his youth, he once studied archery, but his strength was insufficient to draw a strong bow—only one like Yan Gao’s. He believed archery was among the Six Arts and could be used to repel bandits, resist raids, and hunt birds and beasts, so he practiced it. Once, while in the military, he shot at pursuing cavalry, striking down two enemies and a horse, thereby escaping death. He also learned the use of the shield and single- and double-edged swords, all with oral formulas and essential techniques for subduing opponents. There were even secret methods so skillful they seemed divine. When facing the untrained, he could single-handedly prevail, advancing without hindrance.

Later, he learned the seven-foot staff technique, which could be used to disarm opponents or break through defenses. Yet this, too, was a non-essential skill—knowing it was like possessing the horn of a qilin or the spur of a phoenix: what need was there for it? Few in his time understood such things.

From a young age, Ge Hong had a steadfast resolve never to enter officialdom. Whenever he read the biographies of Chao Fu, Xu You, the northern recluse of Zizhou, the two Jiangs of Shihu, the two Xiaos, Fazhen, and Zilong, he would set aside his books and lean forward in admiration. He aspired to master the Five Classics and compose a work of his own, so that later generations would know him as a literary scholar. Later, when the prefecture and the General of Chariots and Cavalry summoned him, he declined. Though recommended to the prime minister’s office of the Prince of Langye, when the uprising began and the rebels were pacified, he did not seek recognition or visit the office to claim merit. The officials in charge never rewarded his contributions.

He hoped that the King of Jin, who answered Heaven’s call and followed the people’s will, would restore order, revive the fading imperial lineage, repair the neglected ancestral temples, and honor the unrecognized merits of the previous dynasty to encourage future service. Ge Hong followed the general amnesty and, in the year *gengyin*, received an edict granting him the title of Marquis of Guanzhong, with a fief of two hundred households in Jurong. He had secretly led troops to suppress rebels and save his homeland, but his efforts were deemed insufficient for record. The honor of golden and purple seals was not his original aspiration. He had wished to emulate Lu Lian from afar and Tian Chou more closely, submitting petitions to decline and fulfill his reclusive ambitions. However, a general amnesty was in place, and his request was not granted.

In the past, Zhong You declined a reward he was due, yet this discouraged others from doing good. The barbarians had not yet been pacified, the realm was troubled, and the state sought to clarify rewards and punishments to uphold the law. How could a humble man like himself stubbornly cling to his timid resolve and resist the grand, all-encompassing system? Thus, he set aside his personal inclinations and respectfully accepted the imperial decree.

After Ge Hong wrote his autobiographical essay, someone challenged him, saying: "In his later years, Wang Chong feared his name and deeds would perish, so he wrote an account of himself. You, however, are in the prime of life, living in an era of sagely rule. You should be untying the silk bundles of Shen Gong and mounting the rush mats of Mei Sheng, illuminating the Nine Five with your brilliance and surpassing the fame of Kunwu. Why instead pursue the path of an old scholar, wasting your fragrance?"

Ge Hong replied: "Heaven and Earth stretch vast, yet man dwells as if in a borrowed abode. The morning mushroom’s brief bloom withers before the day is done; the spring flower’s glory fades within ten days. Even the fleeting flight of the whirlwind or the sudden flash of lightning are not necessarily swifter. The span of a hundred years is like a shooting star’s swift passage; gray hair flies by like an arrow through a gap. How much more so for those who wither in summer’s heat or perish before autumn’s chill? Thus, Xiangzi lamented the unharvested grain, and Yang Xiong mourned his early death.

"Looking back through the ages, extraordinary men have risen like dragons through literary arts or crouched like tigers through martial deeds. Their great merits are recorded in the bright halls, their virtuous reputations echoing through the bamboo and silk. Though their forms may decay in the earth, their fine reputations soar with the days. Even after a thousand or ten thousand generations, they remain revered.

"I, however, am mediocre and obscure, my steps out of sync with the times, my voice discordant with the world. My steps clash with the crowd, and within, I lack the support of the Jin or Zhang families; without, I have no friends to dust off their hats for me. Though the path may be smooth, my feet are not those of a *qilin*; though the skies may be vast, my wings are not those of the great peng. Above, I cannot soar like a hawk to aid the state; below, I cannot glorify my parents or leave behind a name. My virtues are not entrusted to good historians, nor is my fame inscribed on bells and tripods. Thus, in the margins of my writings, I have composed this autobiographical essay. Though it may not alter my fate, I rely on future generations to carry on the record."

*Baopuzi, Outer Chapters, Scroll Four*
